These results highlight the importance of chromatin structure in regulating homologous recombination and suggest that permissive structure at the donor will be an important design parameter in developing donor genes for therapeutic applications. Furthermore, our findings have implications for understanding how chromatin structure affects gene conversion and homologous recombination more generally.
Title: Revisiting the Role of Climbing Fibers in Cerebellum-Based Motor Learning: Evidence for Error Memory in Saccadic Adaptation

    Abstract:
    The cerebellum plays a crucial role in adjusting motor behavior to meet the demands of a given situation. Traditionally, it has been assumed that cerebellum-based motor learning is guided by the difference between desired and actual behavior, with error information driving lasting changes in parallel fiber synapses on Purkinje cells (PCs). Climbing fibers, originating from the inferior olive, are thought to convey instant error information for synaptic modification, but not to contribute to error memory. Here, we investigated the role of climbing fibers in saccadic learning using a random error saccadic adaptation paradigm in monkeys. Our results reveal a clear complex spike (CS) signature of the error at the time of its occurrence, as well as a reverberation of this signature much later, before a new manifestation of the behavior. This finding suggests that climbing fibers may play a more significant role in error memory than previously thought.

    Methods:
    We used a random error saccadic adaptation paradigm to study cerebellum-based motor learning in monkeys. This paradigm allowed us to avoid the gradual buildup of strong behavioral changes and the accompanying diminution of the error, which can obscure the electrophysiological fingerprint of the original error.

    Main Findings:
    Our results show a clear CS signature of the error at the time of its occurrence, as well as a reverberation of this signature much later, before a new manifestation of the behavior. This suggests that climbing fibers may play a more significant role in error memory than previously thought.

    Implications:
    Our findings have significant implications for our understanding of cerebellum-based motor learning. They suggest that climbing fibers may not only convey instant error information but also contribute to error memory, allowing for lasting changes in behavior. This challenges the traditional view of the role of climbing fibers in cerebellum-based motor learning.

    Conclusions:
    Our study provides new insights into the role of climbing fibers in cerebellum-based motor learning. The results suggest that climbing fibers may play a more significant role in error memory than previously thought, and that they may contribute to lasting changes in behavior. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms underlying cerebellum-based motor learning and the role of climbing fibers in this process.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Hsp40 Chaperone Sis1 and its Mammalian Homologue DNAJB1 Exert Neuroprotective Effects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)

    **Background:** Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease characterized by the selective loss of motor neurons and the formation of cytoplasmic aggregates containing the RNA/DNA binding protein TDP-43. Using a yeast model of ALS, we investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying TDP-43 toxicity and identified potential therapeutic targets.

    **Research Question:** Can the Hsp40 chaperone Sis1 and its mammalian homologue DNAJB1 mitigate TDP-43 toxicity and aggregation in yeast and mammalian neurons?

    **Methods:** We employed a yeast model of ALS exhibiting TDP-43 dependent toxicity and overexpressed TDP-43 in yeast and primary rodent cortical neurons. We also overexpressed Sis1 and its mammalian homologue DNAJB1 to assess their effects on TDP-43 toxicity and aggregation.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that TDP-43 overexpression dramatically alters cell shape and reduces ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis of a reporter construct in yeast. Notably, excess Sis1 reduced TDP-43's effect on toxicity, cell shape, and proteolysis. Furthermore, overexpression of DNAJB1, the mammalian Sis1 homologue, relieved TDP-43-mediated toxicity in primary rodent cortical neurons.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that Sis1 and its mammalian homologue DNAJB1 may have neuroprotective effects in ALS by mitigating TDP-43 toxicity and aggregation. The identification of Sis1 as a modifier of TDP-43 toxicity in yeast and DNAJB1 in mammalian neurons highlights the potential of Hsp40 chaperones as therapeutic targets for ALS.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying TDP-43 toxicity and identifies Sis1 and DNAJB1 as potential therapeutic candidates for ALS. Further research is needed to determine if the protection afforded by Sis1 and DNAJB1 can be an effective means of extending neuronal survival in ALS and related conditions characterized by cytoplasmic mislocalization and aggregation of DNA/RNA binding proteins.
Title: Molecular Typing and Parasite Load Quantification of Trypanosoma cruzi Discrete Typing Units in Chronic Chagas Disease Patients from Brazil

    Abstract:
    Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, remains a significant public health concern in Latin America. This study aimed to investigate the association between Trypanosoma cruzi discrete typing units (DTUs) and clinical manifestations of the disease in 65 chronic Chagas disease patients from Brazil. We employed a multilocus conventional PCR and quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) approaches to perform molecular typing and parasite load quantification directly from blood specimens. Our results showed that 53.8% of patients presented positive amplification by qPCR, with 30.7% having the clinical indeterminate form and 23.1% having the cardiac form of the disease. Notably, the parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old (median 20.05 [18.29-86.86] parasite equivalents/mL). We were able to genotype the parasite in 80% of patients with positive qPCR, identifying TcVI, TcII, and mixed infection TcVI+TcII in 40%, 17.1%, and 14.3% of patients, respectively. Patients infected by TcII had higher parasite loads (median 7.56 par. Eq./mL) compared to those infected by TcVI (median 2.35 par. Eq./mL). However, patients infected by TcVI had a higher frequency of chronic chagasic cardiomyopathy (CCC) (50%) compared to those infected by TcII (16.7%). Our findings contribute to updating the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and highlight the age of the patient and infection by TcII as important factors leading to higher parasitemia levels.

    Methods:
    We recruited 65 chronic Chagas disease patients from a single health center in Brazil, with their place of birth distributed across different geographic regions. Blood samples were collected and processed for serological and molecular diagnosis tests. We used a multilocus conventional PCR and qPCR approaches to perform molecular typing and parasite load quantification directly from blood specimens.

    Main Findings:
    Our results showed that 53.8% of patients presented positive amplification by qPCR, with 30.7% having the clinical indeterminate form and 23.1% having the cardiac form of the disease. The parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old (median 20.05 [18.29-86.86] par. Eq./mL). We were able to genotype the parasite in 80% of patients with positive qPCR, identifying TcVI, TcII, and mixed infection TcVI+TcII in 40%, 17.1%, and 14.3% of patients, respectively. Patients infected by TcII had higher parasite loads (median 7.56 par. Eq./mL) compared to those infected by TcVI (median 2.35 par. Eq./mL).

    Implications:
    Our findings contribute to updating the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and highlight the age of the patient and infection by TcII as important factors leading to higher parasitemia levels.

    Conclusions:
    This study provides valuable insights into the molecular typing and parasite load quantification of T. cruzi DTUs in chronic Chagas disease patients from Brazil. Our results suggest that the age of the patient and infection by TcII are important factors leading to higher parasitemia levels, which may have implications for the diagnosis and treatment of Chagas disease.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Enhanced Bat Rabies Surveillance in Guatemala Reveals Low Prevalence and Phylogenetic Relationships of Rabies Virus

    **Research Question:** What is the prevalence of rabies virus (RABV) in bats in Guatemala, and what are the phylogenetic relationships of the detected viruses?

    **Methods:** Between 2009 and 2011, a total of 672 bats of 31 species were sampled and tested for RABV in Guatemala as part of a larger pathogen detection program. Viral antigens were detected and infectious virus was isolated from the brains of two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus). RABV was also isolated from oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats, and viral RNA was detected in all tissues examined by hemi-nested RT-PCR.

    **Main Findings:** The prevalence of RABV detection among all collected bats was low (0.3%). Two vampire bat RABV isolates were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in the eastern states of Mexico and El Salvador. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein gene showed that both viruses were 100% identical, while sequencing of the glycoprotein gene revealed one non-synonymous substitution (302T, S). Additionally, 7% of sera collected from 398 bats demonstrated RABV neutralizing antibody.

    **Implications:** The low prevalence of RABV in bats in Guatemala suggests that the virus may not be as widespread as previously thought. However, the detection of RABV exposure among multiple species of bats in Guatemala highlights the complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RABV perpetuation. The phylogenetic relationships of the detected viruses suggest that RABV may have been introduced to Guatemala and El Salvador via eastern Mexico.

    **Conclusions:** This study provides the first report and isolation of RABV from bats in Guatemala, highlighting the need for novel strategies to prevent and control bat-associated zoonoses in tropical regions. The low prevalence of RABV in bats in Guatemala suggests that the virus may not be as widespread as previously thought, but the detection of RABV exposure among multiple species of bats highlights the complex dynamics of RABV perpetuation.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** The Nuclear Lamina Regulates Heterochromatin and Gene Activation in Herpes Simplex Virus Infection

    **Research Question:** What is the role of the nuclear lamina in regulating heterochromatin and gene activation during Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infection?

    **Methods:** We examined HSV infection in wild-type (WT) and A-type lamin-deficient (Lmna−/−) murine embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) using chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that the nuclear lamina plays a crucial role in regulating heterochromatin and gene activation during HSV infection. In Lmna−/− cells, viral replication compartments are reduced in size and fail to target to the nuclear periphery, as observed in WT cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies demonstrate that HSV DNA is associated with increased heterochromatin in Lmna−/− MEFs. Furthermore, lamin A/C is required for targeting of the viral genome and the reduction of heterochromatin on viral promoters during lytic infection.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the nuclear lamina serves as a molecular scaffold for DNA genomes and the protein complexes that regulate both euchromatin and heterochromatin histone modifications. The nuclear lamina may play an additional role in providing a platform for recruitment of viral DNA as well as chromatin-modifying enzymes that keep the viral genome in an active chromatin conformation.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides evidence that the nuclear lamina regulates heterochromatin and gene activation during HSV infection, and that lamin A/C is required for targeting of the viral genome and the reduction of heterochromatin on viral promoters. These findings have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms of viral infection and the regulation of chromatin structure. Further studies should determine the precise mechanism by which the nuclear lamins are exploited by HSV to keep its genome transcriptionally active during productive infection.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Unveiling the Diversity of Mitochondrial Translocases: Insights from Hydrogenosomes of Trichomonas vaginalis

    **Research Question:** What is the structure and function of the translocase of the outer membrane (TOM) complex in hydrogenosomes, a metabolically specialized form of mitochondria found in the excavate Trichomonas vaginalis?

    **Methods:** We isolated and characterized the TOM complex from hydrogenosomes of T. vaginalis using a combination of bioinformatics, biochemical, and electron microscopy techniques.

    **Main Findings:** Our results reveal that the highly divergent β-barrel T. vaginalis TOM (TvTom) 40-2 forms a translocation channel to conduct hydrogenosomal protein import. We identified four tail-anchored (TA) proteins associated with TvTom, including Tom36 and Tom46, which can bind hydrogenosomal preproteins and likely function as receptors. Additionally, we found a Tom22-like protein with a short cis domain and a conserved Tom22 transmembrane segment, but lacking a trans domain. Furthermore, our data indicate that TvTOM is associated with sorting and assembly machinery (Sam) 50 involved in β-barrel assembly. Electron microscopy revealed that TvTOM forms three pores and has an unconventional skull-like shape.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the triplet-pore TOM complex, composed of three conserved subunits, was present in the last common eukaryotic ancestor (LECA), while receptors responsible for substrate binding evolved independently in different eukaryotic lineages.

    **Conclusions:** This study provides new insights into the diversity of mitochondrial translocases and sheds light on the evolution of protein import pathways in eukaryotes. Our results demonstrate that the TOM complex in hydrogenosomes of T. vaginalis has a unique structure and function compared to other eukaryotes, highlighting the complexity and adaptability of mitochondrial translocases in different eukaryotic lineages. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of eukaryotic cells and the function of mitochondria in different organisms.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Elucidating the Genetic Regulation of Autoimmune Diseases through Cell Type-Specific eQTL Mapping in CD4+ and CD8+ T Cells

    **Research Question:** How do genetic polymorphisms regulate the expression of genes associated with autoimmune diseases in CD4+ and CD8+ T cells?

    **Methods:** We employed eQTL (expression quantitative trait locus) mapping in purified CD4+ and CD8+ T cells to investigate the effects of genetic variants on the regulation of genes associated with autoimmune diseases.

    **Main Findings:** Our study revealed cell type-specific regulation of transcript levels of genes associated with several autoimmune diseases, including a trans-acting regulatory locus at chr12q13.2 containing the rs1131017 SNP in the RPS26 gene. Notably, we identified a common missense variant in IL27, associated with type 1 diabetes (T1D), which results in decreased functional activity of the protein and reduced expression levels of downstream IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells only.

    **Implications:** Our results indicate that eQTL mapping in purified T cells provides novel functional insights into polymorphisms and pathways associated with autoimmune diseases. Specifically, we found that the rs181206[G] variant of the IL27 gene confers protection against T1D through the inhibited expression of IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells. Conversely, IL-27 may promote autoimmunity toward pancreatic islets via the upregulation of the STAT1 pathway.

    **Conclusions:** Our study highlights the importance of cell type-specific eQTL mapping in understanding the genetic regulation of the immune system and its cellular phenotypes. The identification of a common missense variant in IL27 as a significant trans-eQTL for IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells provides new insights into the basic processes of gene expression regulation in T cells and advances our understanding of the pathways involved in disease susceptibility in the adaptive immune system. These findings have significant implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for autoimmune diseases.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Understanding Socio-Cultural and Economic Barriers to Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) Screening and Treatment in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)

    **Research Question:** What are the socio-cultural and economic factors that hinder the uptake of screening and treatment of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), and how can these barriers be addressed to enhance the effectiveness of HAT control?

    **Methods:** This qualitative study employed semi-structured interviews and focus group discussions with current and former HAT patients, healthcare providers, and program managers of the national HAT control program in the Bandundu and Kasaï Oriental provinces, two provinces lagging behind in the HAT elimination effort. Data were analyzed using the ATLAS.ti software.

    **Main Findings:** Our study revealed that community-enforced prohibitions, such as abstaining from work, sexual intercourse, hot food, and walking in the sun for six months after HAT treatment, significantly deter people from participating in HAT screening campaigns. These prohibitions, originally intended to mitigate the adverse effects of the melarsoprol regimen, are no longer evidence-based and have become obsolete with the introduction of safer drugs. However, they remain deeply ingrained in the community, leading to sub-optimal uptake of HAT screening and treatment.

    **Implications:** The findings of this study highlight the need for a better understanding of these prohibitions, their origin, and their rationale to improve HAT control strategies in DRC. Addressing these socio-cultural and economic barriers is crucial to enhance the effectiveness of HAT control efforts.

    **Conclusions:** Our study demonstrates that medical advice related to HAT management has transformed into a series of strictly enforced taboos, which are a significant determinant of sub-optimal uptake of HAT screening campaigns. Abandoning these taboos may be possible with the wider availability of safer and more effective treatment options, such as NECT. The findings of this study have important implications for the development of targeted interventions to improve community participation in HAT screening and treatment activities, ultimately contributing to the attainment of the national control program's objectives.
Title: Estimating Visceral Leishmaniasis Incidence and Mortality in Eastern Gedaref State, Sudan: A Door-to-Door Survey

    Abstract:
    Background: Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a significant public health concern in Sudan, particularly in eastern Gedaref State. We conducted a door-to-door survey to estimate VL incidence and mortality rates in 45 villages of Al-Gureisha locality.

    Research Question: What is the incidence and mortality rate of visceral leishmaniasis in eastern Gedaref State, Sudan?

    Methods: Between May 5th and June 17th, 2011, we conducted an exhaustive door-to-door survey in 45 villages, interviewing 17,702 households with a population of 94,369 inhabitants. Verbal autopsies were conducted to investigate deaths, and individuals with fever of at least two weeks, previous VL diagnosis, or clinical suspicion of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) were referred to medical teams for case ascertainment.

    Main Findings: The crude mortality rate over the mean recall period of 409 days was 0.13/10,000 people per day. VL was a possible or probable cause for 19% of all deaths, resulting in a VL-specific mortality rate of 0.9/1000 per year. The overall incidence of VL over the past year was 7.0/1000 persons per year, or 7.9/1000 per year when deaths possibly or probably due to VL were included. A total of 12.5% (11,943/95,609) of the population reported a past VL treatment episode.

    Implications: Our study highlights the significant health burden of VL in eastern Gedaref State. The low yield of active VL case detection in this setting with adequate access to care suggests that this approach may not be the priority intervention to enhance control in similar contexts.

    Conclusions: This study provides valuable insights into the epidemiology of VL in eastern Gedaref State, Sudan. The high incidence and mortality rates emphasize the need for effective control measures, such as vector-control strategies, to reduce the transmission of this disease. Our findings also underscore the importance of considering the self-healing nature of PKDL in Sudan and the potential toxicity of the recommended SSG treatment.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    Title: Elucidating the Mechanism of Negative Supercoiling in Bacterial Chromosomes: A Role for Gyrase and Transcription Elongation Rates

    Research Question: What is the relationship between gyrase activity, transcription elongation rates, and supercoil density in bacterial chromosomes?

    Methods: We employed a 9 kb “supercoil sensor” inserted at ten positions around the genome of Salmonella enterica to monitor both supercoil density and transcription elongation rates in wild-type (WT) and mutant strains. The sensor contains a complete Lac operon flanked by directly repeated resolvase binding sites.

    Main Findings: Our results show that RNA transcription causes negative supercoiling to increase upstream and decrease downstream of highly expressed genes. Excess upstream supercoiling was relaxed by Topoisomerase I (Topo I), and gyrase replenished downstream supercoil losses to maintain an equilibrium state. Strains with temperature-sensitive (TS) gyrase mutations exhibited significant supercoil losses varying from 30% of WT levels to a total loss of diffusible supercoil density (σD) at most chromosome locations. Supercoil losses were influenced by transcription, as addition of rifampicin (Rif) caused supercoil density to rebound throughout the chromosome. Gyrase mutants that caused dramatic supercoil losses also reduced transcription elongation rates throughout the genome.

    Implications: Our findings suggest that the mean supercoil density of Salmonella DNA is determined by a mechanism that links the catalytic efficiency of gyrase to the elongation rate of transcription. The observed link between RNA polymerase elongation speed and gyrase turnover suggests that bacteria with fast growth rates may generate higher supercoil densities than slow-growing species.

    Conclusions: Our study provides new insights into the relationship between gyrase activity, transcription elongation rates, and supercoil density in bacterial chromosomes. The results suggest that gyrase plays a critical role in maintaining supercoil density, and that transcription elongation rates influence supercoil levels. These findings have implications for our understanding of bacterial chromosome organization and the regulation of gene expression.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Host Innate Response to Leishmania amazonensis Infection: Upregulation of LYST/Beige Regulates Parasitophorous Vacuole Size and Parasite Survival

    **Background:** Leishmania amazonensis, a protozoan parasite, replicates within parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) that share characteristics with late endosomes/lysosomes. However, the impact of PV size on parasite intracellular survival remains unclear.

    **Research Question:** Does the upregulation of LYST/Beige, a gene implicated in regulating lysosome size, influence PV expansion and Leishmania amazonensis replication?

    **Methods:** We investigated the expression of LYST/Beige in host cells infected with L. amazonensis and examined the effects of LYST/Beige mutations and overexpression on PV size and parasite growth.

    **Main Findings:** We found that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate LYST/Beige transcription, which leads to reduced PV expansion and inhibited parasite growth. Conversely, LYST/Beige mutations caused further PV expansion and enhanced L. amazonensis replication. Overexpression of LYST/Beige resulted in small PVs that did not sustain parasite growth, while treatment with vacuolin-1 reversed this phenotype, expanding PVs and promoting parasite growth. Inhibition of nitric oxide synthase had no effect on L. amazonensis viability within large PVs, but enhanced their growth within LYST/Beige-induced small PVs.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the upregulation of LYST/Beige in infected cells functions as a host innate response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV volume and inhibiting intracellular survival.

    **Conclusions:** This study provides direct experimental evidence for the idea that increased expression of LYST/Beige restricts Leishmania growth by counteracting PV expansion. Our results suggest that targeting L. amazonensis PV expansion might lead to novel therapeutic strategies against human infections caused by this pathogen.
Title: Elucidating the Pathophysiological Mechanisms of Allan-Herndon-Dudley Syndrome: A Zebrafish Model Reveals the Therapeutic Potential of Thyroid Hormone Analogues

    Abstract:
    Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (AHDS) is a rare X-linked disorder characterized by severe intellectual disability, muscle hypotonia, and spastic paraplegia, associated with mutations in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 (MCT8) gene. To investigate the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying AHDS, we generated an MCT8 knockout (mct8−/−) zebrafish model using zinc-finger nuclease (ZFN)-mediated targeted gene editing. Our results demonstrate that mct8−/− larvae exhibit neurological and behavioral deficiencies, including reduced locomotor activity, altered response to external light and dark transitions, and increased sleep time. High-throughput behavioral assays revealed that these deficiencies are associated with altered expression of myelin-related genes and neuron-specific deficiencies in circuit formation. Time-lapse imaging of single-axon arbors and synapses in live mct8−/− larvae revealed a reduction in filopodia dynamics and axon branching in sensory neurons and decreased synaptic density in motor neurons. Notably, the administration of thyroid hormone (TH) analogues that can enter cells in the absence of MCT8 restored the myelin and axon outgrowth deficiencies in mct8−/− larvae. These findings suggest a mechanism by which MCT8 regulates neural circuit assembly, ultimately mediating sensory and motor control of behavioral performance. Furthermore, our results propose that the administration of TH analogues early during embryo development can specifically reduce neurological damage in AHDS patients. This study provides new insights into the pathophysiological mechanisms of AHDS and highlights the therapeutic potential of TH analogues in treating this disorder.

    Research Question:
    What are the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (AHDS), and can thyroid hormone analogues be used to treat this disorder?

    Methods:
    We generated an MCT8 knockout (mct8−/−) zebrafish model using zinc-finger nuclease (ZFN)-mediated targeted gene editing. We performed high-throughput behavioral assays, time-lapse imaging of single-axon arbors and synapses, and pharmacological rescue experiments to investigate the effects of MCT8 deficiency on neural circuit assembly and behavior.

    Main Findings:
    Our results show that mct8−/− larvae exhibit neurological and behavioral deficiencies, including reduced locomotor activity, altered response to external light and dark transitions, and increased sleep time. These deficiencies are associated with altered expression of myelin-related genes and neuron-specific deficiencies in circuit formation. Time-lapse imaging revealed a reduction in filopodia dynamics and axon branching in sensory neurons and decreased synaptic density in motor neurons.

    Implications:
    Our findings suggest that MCT8 regulates neural circuit assembly, ultimately mediating sensory and motor control of behavioral performance. The administration of TH analogues that can enter cells in the absence of MCT8 restored the myelin and axon outgrowth deficiencies in mct8−/− larvae, highlighting the therapeutic potential of TH analogues in treating AHDS.

    Conclusions:
    This study provides new insights into the pathophysiological mechanisms of AHDS and highlights the therapeutic potential of TH analogues in treating this disorder. Our results propose that the administration of TH analogues early during embryo development can specifically reduce neurological damage in AHDS patients.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Formation of Stable gB-gH/gL Complexes in Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) Virions: Implications for Herpesvirus Entry Models

    **Background:** Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a major pathogen in newborns and immunocompromised patients, utilizing distinct entry pathways involving different forms of the gH/gL glycoprotein and the viral fusion glycoprotein, gB.

    **Research Question:** Do HCMV gB and gH/gL form a stable complex early after their synthesis and in the absence of other viral proteins, and if so, what are the implications for herpesvirus entry models?

    **Methods:** We employed biochemical and biophysical approaches to investigate the interaction between HCMV gB and gH/gL, including co-immunoprecipitation and fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) analyses.

    **Main Findings:** We demonstrate that HCMV gB and gH/gL form a stable complex early after their synthesis and in the absence of other viral proteins. This complex includes up to 16-50% of the total gH/gL in HCMV virus particles. Notably, gH/gL can interact with gB mutants that are unable to mediate cell-cell fusion, suggesting that gB does not require fusion competence to interact with gH/gL.

    **Implications:** Our results have major implications for herpesvirus entry models, which suggest that gH/gL interacts with gB to mediate membrane fusion. Our data provide direct evidence that HCMV gB and gH/gL form stable complexes that are incorporated into virions without receptor binding or membrane fusion, supporting the proposal that gH/gL interacts with gB.

    **Conclusions:** Our findings challenge the prevailing view that gH/gL is activated by receptor binding and then binds to gB to trigger fusion. Instead, our results suggest that gB and gH/gL form a stable complex before gB is activated for fusion and entry. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of herpesvirus entry mechanisms and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies to prevent HCMV infection.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Gimap3 Regulates Mitochondrial DNA Segregation in Leukocytes: Implications for Human Mitochondrial Diseases

    **Research Question:** What is the role of Gimap3, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, in regulating the segregation of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sequence variants in leukocytes, and what are the implications for human mitochondrial diseases?

    **Methods:** We used a heteroplasmic mouse model to investigate the genetic regulation of mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues. We identified Gimap3 as a critical regulator of mtDNA segregation in leukocytes and demonstrated its importance for T cell development and survival.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that Gimap3 is a nuclear-encoded gene that influences mtDNA segregation in mammals. We found that Gimap3 regulates the rate of mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues and that segregation of mtDNA haplotypes in mouse hematopoietic tissues is a complex genetic trait regulated with age, independent of mtDNA copy number. We also demonstrated that altered mRNA splicing for the CAST/Ei allele changes the Gimap3 protein sequence in the soluble domain, but not the C-terminal transmembrane domain, which anchors and localizes it to the outer mitochondrial membrane.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that Gimap3 is a critical gene for regulating mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues and that leukocyte survival may be a key factor in the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and in modulating human mitochondrial diseases. The mechanisms by which Gimap3 regulates mtDNA segregation are unclear, but our results imply that a cell-specific context or pathway is required to alter mtDNA segregation.

    **Conclusions:** This study identifies Gimap3 as the first nuclear-encoded gene that influences mtDNA segregation in mammals and highlights the importance of Gimap3 in regulating mtDNA segregation in leukocytes. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and the pathogenesis of human mitochondrial diseases. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms by which Gimap3 regulates mtDNA segregation and to explore its potential as a therapeutic target for mitochondrial diseases.
Title: Estimating the Incubation Period of Buruli Ulcer in Victoria, Australia: A Retrospective Review of 443 Cases

    Abstract:

    Background: Buruli ulcer (BU) is a geographically-restricted infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, with contact with endemic regions being the primary risk factor for disease acquisition. However, estimating the incubation period (IP) of BU is often hindered by the fact that most patients reside permanently in endemic areas.

    Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of 443 cases of BU notified in Victoria, Australia between 2013 and 2016. Telephone interviews were performed to identify cases with a single visit to an endemic region or multiple visits within a one-month period. The incubation period was defined as the time between exposure to an endemic region and symptom onset.

    Main Findings: Among the 20 new cases identified in short-term visitors, the mean incubation period was 143 days (4.8 months), similar to the previous estimate of 135 days (4.5 months). We found no association between incubation period and age, sex, location of exposure, duration of exposure to an endemic region, or location of BU lesion.

    Implications: Our study confirms the mean incubation period of BU in Victoria to be between 4 and 5 months. This knowledge can guide clinicians and suggests that the mode of transmission of BU is similar in different geographic regions in Victoria.

    Conclusions: Our estimate of an incubation period of 4.8 months (range 2-9 months) for Buruli ulcer confirms a previous similar estimate derived from an earlier group of patients who mostly acquired their infections in a different geographic location. This suggests that the mode of disease transmission is similar in different Victorian endemic regions. Our findings have important implications for the diagnosis and management of BU in non-residents of endemic areas, where delayed diagnosis is more common due to the prolonged incubation period.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Unveiling the Role of TgNCR1 in Lipid Homeostasis in Toxoplasma gondii

    **Research Question:** What is the function of the Toxoplasma gondii protein TgNCR1 in lipid homeostasis, and how does it contribute to the parasite's survival and virulence?

    **Methods:** We investigated the role of TgNCR1, a protein containing the sterol-sensing domain (SSD), in Toxoplasma gondii. We generated a parasite cell line lacking TgNCR1 (ΔNCR1) and performed quantitative lipidomic analyses to examine the effects on lipid levels. We also expressed TgNCR1 in mammalian NPC1 mutant cells and assessed its ability to restore cholesterol and GM1 clearance from endo-lysosomes.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that TgNCR1 is a close relative of human NPC1 and localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the plasma membrane of Toxoplasma. When targeted to mammalian endo-lysosomes, TgNCR1 restores lipid trafficking from these organelles in mammalian NPC1 mutant cells. The ΔNCR1 strain exhibits normal cholesterol levels but overaccumulates several species of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyelins, and ceramides. Moreover, ΔNCR1 parasites display abundant storage lipid bodies and long membranous tubules derived from their parasitophorous vacuoles.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that TgNCR1 plays a crucial role in lipid homeostasis in Toxoplasma gondii, regulating the intracellular levels of several lipids. The loss of TgNCR1 function leads to the stimulation of lipid storage, membrane biosynthesis, and parasite division, resulting in faster replication in vitro and increased virulence in mice.

    **Conclusions:** Based on these observations, we ascribe a role for TgNCR1 in lipid homeostasis in Toxoplasma gondii. Our results provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying lipid regulation in this intracellular parasite and highlight the potential of TgNCR1 as a target for the development of novel therapeutic strategies against Toxoplasmosis.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Loss of SMOC1 Function Causes Ophthalmo-Acromelic Syndrome: Insights from Human Genetics and Mouse Modeling

    **Research Question:** What is the genetic basis of Ophthalmo-Acromelic Syndrome (OAS), a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by eye malformations and post-axial oligosyndactyly?

    **Methods:** We employed a combination of homozygosity mapping, targeted mutation analysis, and mouse modeling to identify the genetic cause of OAS. We analyzed eight unrelated families with OAS and identified homozygous mutations in the SMOC1 gene on chromosome 14q24.2. We also generated a targeted pre-conditional gene-trap mouse mutation of Smoc1, which resulted in a convincing phenocopy of the human disease.

    **Main Findings:** We identified four nonsense, two frameshift, and two missense mutations in SMOC1 in eight unrelated families with OAS. The missense mutations were located in the second Thyroglobulin Type-1 (Tg1) domain of the protein. We also generated a targeted pre-conditional gene-trap mouse mutation of Smoc1, which resulted in highly penetrant hindlimb post-axial oligosyndactyly, eye malformations, and cleft palate in homozygous mutant animals. The mouse phenotype showed significant overlap with the human disease.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that loss of SMOC1 function is the major cause of OAS. SMOC-1 is a mammalian paralog of Drosophila Pentagone, an inhibitor of decapentaplegic, and functions as a Bone Morphogenic Protein (BMP) antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagonism during mammalian development provides a plausible explanation for both the limb and eye phenotype in humans and mice.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides strong evidence for the genetic basis of OAS and highlights the conserved non-redundant function of SMOC-1 during ocular and limb development. The mouse model generated in this study provides a valuable tool for understanding the pathogenesis of OAS and may facilitate the development of therapeutic strategies for this devastating disorder.
Title: Identification of TRIM22 as a Key Mediator of Type 1 Interferon-Induced Restriction of HIV Replication

    Abstract:

    Background: Type 1 interferons (IFNs) have been shown to restrict HIV replication in human cells. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying this antiviral activity remain poorly understood.

    Research Question: What is the role of the tripartite motif protein TRIM22 in the restriction of HIV replication by Type 1 interferons?

    Methods: We employed transcriptional profiling to identify cellular genes induced by IFN treatment and identified TRIM22 as one of the most strongly up-regulated genes. We then used RNA interference (RNAi) to deplete TRIM22 in human cells and assessed the effects on HIV replication. We also performed mutational analyses of TRIM22 to determine the functional domains required for its antiviral activity.

    Main Findings: Our results show that TRIM22 is a key mediator of IFN-induced restriction of HIV replication. TRIM22 over-expression inhibited HIV replication, and knockdown of TRIM22 in the context of an IFN response abrogated the late block to HIV replication. We also found that TRIM22 specifically targets the HIV Gag protein, disrupting its proper trafficking and preventing the release of virus-like particles. Mutational analyses revealed that the catalytic amino acids Cys15 and Cys18 of the RING domain are essential for TRIM22's antiviral activity.

    Implications: Our findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the antiviral activity of Type 1 interferons and identify TRIM22 as a key effector molecule in the restriction of HIV replication. These results have important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies to combat HIV infection.

    Conclusions: Our study demonstrates that TRIM22 plays a critical role in the restriction of HIV replication by Type 1 interferons. The identification of TRIM22 as a key mediator of this antiviral activity highlights its potential as a target for the development of novel antiretroviral therapies. Further studies are needed to fully elucidate the mechanisms underlying TRIM22's antiviral activity and to explore its potential as a therapeutic target.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Parasitic Wasps Contribute to Mutualism Stability in Fig-Pollinator Symbiosis

    **Research Question:** What mechanisms prevent pollinating wasps from exploiting all available ovules in monoecious Ficus species, contributing to the stability of the fig-pollinator mutualism?

    **Methods:** We investigated the oviposition behavior of pollinating wasps (Agaonidae) in Ficus rubiginosa and found that offspring in outer ovules are vulnerable to attack by parasitic wasps that oviposit from outside the syconium. We measured the gradient of parasitism risk across the syconium and found that it decreases towards the center, where inner ovules provide enemy-free space for pollinator offspring.

    **Main Findings:** Our results suggest that the resulting gradient in offspring viability contributes to selection on pollinators to avoid outer ovules, reducing their galling rates. This previously unidentified mechanism may contribute to mutualism persistence independent of additional factors that invoke plant defenses against pollinator oviposition or physiological constraints on pollinators.

    **Implications:** Our study reveals that parasitic wasps play a crucial role in maintaining the stability of the fig-pollinator mutualism. By selecting inner ovules for oviposition, pollinating wasps gain a fitness benefit due to reduced vulnerability to parasitism. This finding highlights the importance of considering the interactions between pollinators and parasitic wasps in understanding the dynamics of mutualisms.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying mutualism stability in monoecious Ficus species. The provision of ovules with high variance in profitability to foundresses demonstrates that the fig tree, the larger partner in the symbiosis, controls the resources available to the smaller, more mobile partner, the pollinating wasp. Our results suggest that the fig-pollinator mutualism is more complex than previously thought, with multiple factors contributing to its stability, including the presence of parasitic wasps. This study has important implications for our understanding of the evolution and maintenance of mutualisms in general.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    Title: Dissecting the Genetic and Environmental Components of Plant Height in Setaria: A Recombinant Inbred Line Population Study

    Research Question: How do genetic and environmental factors, including water availability and planting density, influence plant height in an interspecific Setaria italica x Setaria viridis recombinant inbred line population?

    Methods: Six controlled growth trials were conducted in both field and controlled environments to assess the effects of water availability and planting density on plant height in a Setaria RIL population. Non-destructive measurements of plant height were taken throughout the plant life cycle.

    Main Findings: Our results show that plant height is reduced under water limitation and high density planting, and is influenced by growth environment (field vs. growth chamber). The genetic architecture of plant height is heritable and polygenic, with major genetic loci functioning independently of growth environment. The identity and contribution of loci influencing height change dynamically throughout development, and the reduction of growth observed in water-limited environments is a consequence of delayed progression through the genetic program establishing plant height in Setaria.

    Implications: Our study supports a model where plant height is a heritable, polygenic trait that is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. The results suggest that alleles inherited from the weedy S. viridis parent act to increase plant height early, while a larger number of small effect alleles inherited from the domesticated S. italica parent collectively act to increase plant height later in development.

    Conclusions: By combining field and controlled environmental analysis with quantitative genetics, we have dissected the genetic and environmental components of plant height in Setaria. Our findings provide insights into the complex interactions between genetic and environmental factors that influence plant growth and development. The chronological genetic model of plant height may explain differences in plant height observed when parental lines are grown in controlled environments versus field settings. The identification of 37 QTL associated with plant height throughout development highlights the complexity of this trait and underscores the importance of considering temporal and environmental factors in understanding plant growth and development.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Confirmation of Ilheus Virus (ILHV) Circulation in the Brazilian Pantanal through Mosquito Isolation and Molecular Detection

    **Research Question:** Does Ilheus virus (ILHV) circulate in the Brazilian Pantanal, and if so, which mosquito species are involved in its transmission?

    **Methods:** We collected 3,234 adult mosquitoes of 16 species from the Nhecolândia sub-region of the Pantanal between 2009 and 2010. Mosquito pool homogenates were assayed for infectious virus on C6/36 and Vero cell monolayers and tested for flaviviral RNA by group-specific real-time RT-PCR.

    **Main Findings:** One pool containing 50 non-engorged female Aedes scapularis mosquitoes tested positive for ILHV by culture and for ILHV RNA by real-time RT-PCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 1,000. The full-length genomic sequence exhibited 95% identity to the only full genome sequence available for ILHV.

    **Implications:** The present data confirm the circulation of ILHV in the Brazilian Pantanal, a region known for its diverse wildlife species and hematophagous arthropods, which favor the circulation of zoonotic arboviruses. The isolation of ILHV in mosquitoes while attempting to blood feed on a human warrants further investigation of this virus by the Brazilian arbovirus surveillance program and local physicians.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides evidence of ILHV activity in the Nhecolândia sub-region of Pantanal, through the isolation of ILHV from a pool of Ae. scapularis, a mosquito species that has transmitted ILHV efficiently in laboratory vector competence studies. The anthropophilic behavior, relatively high prevalence, and susceptibility to infection of Ae. scapularis implicate this species as a potential vector of ILHV in the region. The confirmation of ILHV circulation in the Brazilian Pantanal highlights the need for continued surveillance and monitoring of arbovirus activity in this region to prevent and control the spread of zoonotic diseases.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Efficacy and Pharmacokinetics of Moxidectin in a Porcine Scabies Model: A Promising Alternative to Ivermectin

    **Research Question:** Can a single oral dose of moxidectin (MOX) be more effective than two consecutive doses of ivermectin (IVM) in treating scabies in a porcine model?

    **Methods:** Twelve pigs were randomly assigned to receive either MOX (0.3 mg/kg once), IVM (0.2 mg/kg twice), or no treatment. Treatment efficacy was evaluated by assessing mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies reductions. Plasma and skin pharmacokinetic profiles were also determined.

    **Main Findings:** At day 14 post-treatment, all four MOX-treated pigs were mite-free, whereas only two IVM-treated pigs were mite-free. MOX efficacy was 100% and remained unchanged until study-end (D47), compared to 62% (range 26-100%) for IVM, with one IVM-treated pig remaining infected until D47. Clinical scabies lesions, pruritus, and anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies had completely disappeared in all MOX-treated but only 75% of IVM-treated pigs. MOX persisted ~9 times longer than IVM in plasma and skin, thereby covering the mite’s entire life cycle and enabling long-lasting efficacy.

    **Implications:** These findings suggest that oral single-dose MOX is more effective than two consecutive IVM doses in treating scabies in a porcine model. Given the growing public health burden of scabies and the emergence of drug resistance in mites, MOX may be a promising alternative therapeutic option.

    **Conclusions:** This preclinical study demonstrates the efficacy and pharmacokinetics of MOX in a porcine scabies model, supporting its potential as a therapeutic approach for scabies. Further studies should investigate the efficacy and dose selection of MOX in humans, including a pivotal Phase II trial for MOX for scabies elimination.
Title: Elucidating the Minimal Peptidoglycan Synthesis Machinery of Staphylococcus aureus: Implications for Antibiotic Resistance and Pathogenicity

    Abstract:
    The peptidoglycan (PG) synthesis machine is a complex molecular assembly responsible for the synthesis of the main component of the bacterial cell wall. In Staphylococcus aureus, a Gram-positive pathogen notorious for its antibiotic resistance and virulence, the PG synthesis machine is composed of nine proteins. To identify the essential components of this machine, we deleted seven of the nine genes encoding PG synthesis enzymes from the S. aureus genome, resulting in a strain capable of PG biosynthesis catalyzed solely by two penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), PBP1 and the bi-functional PBP2. Our results demonstrate that S. aureus can grow and divide with only two active PG synthesizing enzymes, indicating that most of these enzymes are redundant in vitro. However, in clinically relevant environments, bacteria with a minimal PG synthesis machinery became highly susceptible to cell wall-targeting antibiotics, host lytic enzymes, and displayed impaired virulence in a Drosophila infection model. These findings highlight the importance of a complex molecular machine in environments other than in vitro growth, where the expendable PG synthesis enzymes play a crucial role in the pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance of S. aureus. Our study identifies the minimal PG synthesis machinery of S. aureus, which constitutes the most relevant targets for the development of antibiotics capable of inhibiting the final stages of PG synthesis.

    Methods:
    We constructed a S. aureus strain encoding the minimal number of PG synthesis enzymes required for survival by deleting seven of the nine known genes encoding proteins with PG synthesis activity. We used profile Hidden Markov Models (pHMMs) to scan the S. aureus genome and identify close and distantly related homologues of transpeptidase and transglycosylase enzymes.

    Main Findings:
    Our results show that S. aureus cells are capable of PG synthesis catalyzed solely by the transpeptidase PBP1 and the bi-functional PBP2. Interactions between PBPs of Gram-positive organisms have been suggested, but our study provides the first biochemical confirmation of these interactions.

    Implications:
    Our findings have significant implications for the development of antibiotics capable of inhibiting the final stages of PG synthesis. The identification of the minimal PG synthesis machinery of S. aureus highlights the importance of a complex molecular machine in environments other than in vitro growth, where the expendable PG synthesis enzymes play a crucial role in the pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance of S. aureus.

    Conclusions:
    In summary, our study has identified the minimal machinery required for PG synthesis in S. aureus, demonstrating the plasticity of this process. Our results provide new insights into the biology of S. aureus and highlight the importance of a complex molecular machine in environments other than in vitro growth, where the expendable PG synthesis enzymes play a crucial role in the pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance of S. aureus.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    Title: Elucidating Iron Acquisition Pathways in Burkholderia pseudomallei: A Novel Ferritin-Iron Acquisition Pathway Contributes to Virulence

    Background: Burkholderia pseudomallei is a saprophytic bacterium that can infect humans, causing melioidosis, a disease with high mortality rates despite proper diagnosis and treatment. The bacterium's ability to infect, invade, and survive within hosts is not well understood, and little is known about the role of critical nutrients such as iron in its pathogenesis.

    Research Question: What are the iron acquisition pathways employed by Burkholderia pseudomallei, and how do they contribute to its virulence?

    Methods: We generated isogenic mutants of B. pseudomallei strain 1710b with deletions in the major siderophore malleobactin (mba) and pyochelin (pch) gene clusters, as well as the hemin uptake loci hmu and hem. We assessed the residual siderophore activity, iron utilization, and virulence of these mutants in a murine melioidosis model.

    Main Findings: Our results show that B. pseudomallei employs a novel ferritin-iron acquisition pathway as a means to sustain in vivo growth. The mba pch hmu hem quadruple mutant could use ferritin as an iron source and was lethal in an acute murine melioidosis model. We also found that lactoferrin utilization was dependent on malleobactin, but not pyochelin synthesis and/or uptake.

    Implications: Our findings suggest that B. pseudomallei's ability to adapt to adverse conditions within the host may have endowed it to acquire iron in the absence of malleobactin, potentially through upregulation of other siderophores or iron-acquisition mechanisms. The discovery of a novel ferritin-iron acquisition pathway highlights the complexity of B. pseudomallei's iron acquisition strategies and underscores the need for further investigation into its pathogenesis.

    Conclusions: Our study provides new insights into the iron acquisition pathways of B. pseudomallei and highlights the importance of ferritin-iron acquisition in its virulence. These findings have significant implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies against melioidosis, a disease with high mortality rates in tropical and subtropical regions.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** COMMGEN: A Novel Tool for Consensus Metabolic Model Generation and Resolution of Inconsistencies in Genome-Scale Metabolic Models

    **Background:** Genome-scale constraint-based metabolic models (GSMs) are essential for understanding cellular function and predicting metabolic behavior. However, their usability is often hindered by inconsistencies between concurrent models, particularly for eukaryotic organisms, microbial communities, and host-pathogen interactions.

    **Research Question:** Can a novel tool, COMMGEN, automatically identify and resolve inconsistencies between concurrent GSMs, leading to more accurate and comprehensive representations of metabolism?

    **Methods:** We developed COMMGEN, a tool for COnsensus Metabolic Model GENeration, which reconciles two or more distinct GSMs of the same organism beyond a common namespace. COMMGEN automatically identifies similarities, dissimilarities, and complements of the metabolic networks based on an extensive classification of problems that typically arise during GSM integration and novel algorithms to resolve these problem classes.

    **Main Findings:** Our tests of COMMGEN for four organisms showed that automatically generated consensus models were predictive and substantially increased coherence of knowledge representation. Notably, automatically generated consensus models almost always had higher predictive power than manually curated GSMs and were comparable to manually constructed consensus models.

    **Implications:** COMMGEN fills the gap between full automation and high-quality manual curation for consensus metabolic model generation. By reconciling inconsistencies between concurrent models, COMMGEN increases coherence with the actual biological system while maintaining predictive power. This balance is crucial for the usability and reliability of GSMs to elucidate cell function interactions.

    **Conclusions:** COMMGEN is a valuable tool for the scientific community, particularly for complex scenarios where manual curation does not scale. Our results demonstrate the potential of COMMGEN to improve the accuracy and comprehensiveness of metabolic models, ultimately contributing to a deeper understanding of cellular function and its applications in biotechnology and medicine.
Title: Cartilage Proteoglycans Regulate Chondrocyte Maturation and Perichondral Bone Development in Zebrafish

    Abstract:
    Chondrocytes embedded in a proteoglycan (PG)-rich matrix undergo a developmental transition, termed maturation, to induce bone formation in the overlying perichondrium. We investigated the role of PGs in regulating interactions between chondrocytes and perichondrium in zebrafish mutants. Using a mutagenesis screen, we isolated mutants with decreased cartilage matrix and increased perichondral bone formation. Positional cloning identified lesions in two genes, fam20b and xylosyltransferase1 (xylt1), which encode PG synthesis enzymes. Mutants failed to produce wild-type levels of chondroitin sulfate PGs and initiated perichondral bone formation earlier than their wild-type siblings. Primary chondrocyte defects might induce the bone phenotype secondarily, as mutant chondrocytes precociously initiated maturation, showing increased and early expression of markers such as runx2b, collagen type 10a1, and ihh co-orthologs. Ultrastructural analyses demonstrated aberrant matrix organization and early cellular features of chondrocyte hypertrophy in mutants. Our data argue that defective cartilage PG synthesis alters expression of transcription factors that determine the rates of chondrocyte maturation, thus changing the timing of perichondral bone formation.

    Research Question:
    Do cartilage proteoglycans regulate interactions between chondrocytes and perichondrium in zebrafish mutants?

    Methods:
    We used a mutagenesis screen to isolate zebrafish mutants with decreased cartilage matrix and increased perichondral bone formation. Positional cloning identified lesions in two genes, fam20b and xylosyltransferase1 (xylt1), which encode PG synthesis enzymes. We performed biochemical and histochemical analyses to verify matrix defects and ultrastructural analyses to examine cellular features of chondrocyte maturation.

    Main Findings:
    Mutants failed to produce wild-type levels of chondroitin sulfate PGs and initiated perichondral bone formation earlier than their wild-type siblings. Primary chondrocyte defects might induce the bone phenotype secondarily, as mutant chondrocytes precociously initiated maturation, showing increased and early expression of markers such as runx2b, collagen type 10a1, and ihh co-orthologs. Ultrastructural analyses demonstrated aberrant matrix organization and early cellular features of chondrocyte hypertrophy in mutants.

    Implications:
    Our data argue that defective cartilage PG synthesis alters expression of transcription factors that determine the rates of chondrocyte maturation, thus changing the timing of perichondral bone formation.

    Conclusions:
    Cartilage proteoglycans play a critical role in regulating interactions between chondrocytes and perichondrium in zebrafish mutants. Mutations in fam20b and xylt1 genes, which encode PG synthesis enzymes, lead to defective cartilage matrix production and precocious chondrocyte maturation, resulting in early perichondral bone formation. Our findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying skeletal development and highlight the importance of cartilage PGs in regulating chondrocyte maturation and perichondral bone development.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Topoisomerase II is essential for resolving heterochromatic DNA entanglements during meiosis I in Drosophila melanogaster females

    **Research Question:** How do heterochromatic homologs separate during meiosis I in Drosophila melanogaster females, and what role does Topoisomerase II play in this process?

    **Methods:** We used RNA interference (RNAi) to knockdown Topoisomerase II (Top2) in Drosophila melanogaster females during the later stages of meiosis. We analyzed the effects of Top2 RNAi on the separation of heterochromatic regions and the behavior of achiasmate and chiasmate chromosomes during prometaphase I and metaphase I.

    **Main Findings:** Knockdown of Top2 resulted in specific defects in the separation of heterochromatic regions, leading to the formation of long, abnormal projections with centromeres localizing near the tips of the projections. Both achiasmate and chiasmate chromosomes displayed defects in biorientation, and the obligately achiasmate 4th chromosomes failed to move towards the spindle poles during prometaphase I. Despite the presence of bipolar spindles, embryos from Top2 RNAi-expressing females frequently failed to initiate mitotic divisions.

    **Implications:** Our results suggest that Topoisomerase II is essential for resolving heterochromatic DNA entanglements during meiosis I in Drosophila melanogaster females. The failure to resolve these entanglements leads to defects in the separation of heterochromatic regions and the biorientation of achiasmate and chiasmate chromosomes. This, in turn, results in the failure of oocytes to exit meiosis I and initiate mitotic divisions.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides evidence that Topoisomerase II plays a critical role in the resolution of heterochromatic DNA entanglements during meiosis I in Drosophila melanogaster females. The data support the idea that Top2 is involved in releasing the bonds that hold heterochromatic regions together during prophase, allowing for the proper segregation of chromosomes during meiosis I. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the mechanisms underlying meiotic chromosome segregation and the role of Topoisomerase II in this process.
Title: Evaluation of Deltamethrin-Impregnated Collars as a Public Health Measure to Control Canine Visceral Leishmaniasis (CVL) in a Highly Endemic Area of Brazil

    Abstract:

    Background: Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a zoonotic disease of significant public health importance, with limitations in current control measures compromising efficacy. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mass use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars in dogs as a public health measure to control and prevent canine visceral leishmaniasis (CVL) in a highly endemic area of Brazil.

    Methods: An interventional study was conducted in two endemic areas in the district of Monte Gordo, Bahia-Brazil: an intervention area where VL seronegative dogs were collared, and a control area where only conventional CVL control measures were applied. Dogs were reevaluated every 7-8 months for almost two years, with seropositive dogs removed and seronegative dogs included and collared. Local zoonosis control authorities were notified of seropositive dogs, which were subsequently marked for euthanasia as mandated by the Brazilian Ministry of Health.

    Main Findings: At the first serological survey, seroprevalence was similar in both areas. However, significant reductions in seroprevalence were observed in both areas at the second evaluation, with the intervention area reducing to 6.0% during the final evaluation, compared to an increase of 11.0% in the control area. The estimated relative risk (RR = 0.55) indicated protection against CVL in the intervention area.

    Implications: Although CVL incidence did not differ significantly between the areas, an increased tendency was observed in the control area, which could be due to low seroconversion rates or high loss to follow-up. Our evaluation of the effectiveness of deltamethrin-impregnated collars as a community-wide public health control measure was inconclusive, but this measure likely provides protection over time.

    Conclusions: The use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars as a public health measure to control CVL in a highly endemic area of Brazil represents an operational challenge for local zoonosis control authorities, indicating the need for adjustments, including improved collar design. This study contributes to the understanding of the effectiveness of deltamethrin-impregnated collars in controlling CVL and highlights the importance of continued research in this area.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Transcriptional Traffic Jams on the X Chromosome: A Novel Explanation for Biased Gene Content and Expression

    **Research Question:** What is the role of haploid expression of the X chromosome in shaping the gene content and expression of X-linked genes?

    **Methods:** We analyzed gene expression data from The Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) and the Functional Annotation of the Mammalian Genome (FANTOM5) project to investigate the maximal expression levels of human X-linked genes compared to autosomal genes.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that the maximal expression of human X-linked genes is significantly lower than that of autosomal genes, with an average of three times lower maximal expression on the X chromosome than on autosomes. We also found that autosome-to-X retroposition events are associated with lower maximal expression of retrogenes on the X than seen for X-to-autosome retrogenes on autosomes. Furthermore, X-linked genes have a lesser degree of increase in gene expression than autosomal genes compared to the human/Chimpanzee common ancestor, especially for highly expressed genes.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the haploid expression of the X chromosome imposes a limit on the maximal expression level of X-linked genes, leading to biased gene content and expression profiles. This "weak X" model provides a simple yet robust explanation for many peculiar features of X chromosome biology, including the lower breadth of expression for genes on the X and the rarity of highly expressed tissue-specific genes on the X.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides evidence that the haploid expression of the X chromosome is a key factor in shaping the gene content and expression of X-linked genes. The "weak X" model offers a novel perspective on the evolution of gene content on the X chromosome, highlighting the importance of transcriptional traffic jams in limiting the maximal expression of X-linked genes. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of X chromosome biology and the evolution of gene expression in mammals.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Investigating the Prevalence and Population Structure of Helicobacter pylori in Baka Pygmies from Cameroon

    **Research Question:** What is the prevalence and population structure of Helicobacter pylori in Baka Pygmies from Cameroon, and how does it compare to their agriculturalist neighbors?

    **Methods:** Gastric biopsies were obtained from 77 Baka Pygmies and 101 non-Baka individuals from neighboring agriculturalist populations in Cameroon through esophagogastroduodenoscopy. The biopsies were cultured for Helicobacter pylori, and multilocus haplotypes were generated for each isolate by DNA sequencing.

    **Main Findings:** Contrary to expectations, Baka Pygmies showed a significantly lower Helicobacter pylori infection rate (20.8%) compared to non-Baka individuals (80.2%). Most Helicobacter pylori isolates in the Baka sample were assigned to the hpNEAfrica or hpAfrica1 populations. An age-structured transmission model suggested that the low Helicobacter pylori prevalence among Baka Pygmies is achievable within a few hundred years, indicating that demographic factors such as small population size and low life expectancy may lead to the eradication of Helicobacter pylori from individual human populations.

    **Implications:** The findings suggest that Baka Pygmies were either Helicobacter pylori-free or lost their ancient lineages during past demographic fluctuations. Coalescent simulations and phylogenetic inference revealed that Baka Pygmies almost certainly acquired their extant Helicobacter pylori through secondary contact with their agriculturalist neighbors.

    **Conclusions:** This study provides new insights into the prevalence and population structure of Helicobacter pylori in Baka Pygmies from Cameroon. The low Helicobacter pylori infection rate among Baka Pygmies, compared to their agriculturalist neighbors, highlights the importance of demographic factors in shaping the transmission dynamics of this pathogen. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolutionary history of Helicobacter pylori and its relationship with human populations.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    Title: Structural and Functional Analysis of Dengue Virus NS5 Subcellular Localization Reveals Evolutionarily Conserved Motifs

    Background: Dengue virus (DENV) non-structural protein 5 (NS5) is a highly conserved protein among flaviviruses, responsible for capping, methylation, and replication of the viral RNA genome. However, DENV2 NS5 exhibits an unusual characteristic of localizing to the nucleus during infection, despite replication occurring in the cytoplasm.

    Research Question: What are the structural and functional determinants of NS5 subcellular localization in DENV1 and DENV2?

    Methods: We employed a combination of functional and structural analyses, including gene swapping, mutational analysis, and x-ray crystallography, to investigate the subcellular localization of NS5 in DENV1 and DENV2.

    Main Findings: Our results show that the C-terminal 18 residues (Cter18) of NS5 are sufficient to direct the protein to the cytoplasm or nucleus, depending on the serotype. We identified a low micromolar binding affinity between NS5 Cter18 and the nuclear import receptor importin-alpha (Impα), which allowed us to purify and visualize their molecular complex at 2.2 Å resolution using x-ray crystallography. Structure-guided mutational analysis revealed residues important for NS5 subcellular localization, including Pro-884, which allows proper presentation for binding Impα, and R888, which forms a hydrogen bond with Y838 conserved in all flaviviruses.

    Implications: Our findings suggest that the Cter18 of NS5 is an evolutionarily conserved motif that may be involved in RNA interactions critical for replication, independent of its role in subcellular localization. The P884T mutation in DENV2 NS5 results in mislocalization to the cytoplasm without compromising virus fitness, while the R888A mutation leads to a completely non-viable virus, and the R888K mutation results in a severely attenuated phenotype.

    Conclusions: Our study provides new insights into the structural and functional determinants of NS5 subcellular localization in DENV1 and DENV2, and highlights the importance of the Cter18 motif in flavivirus replication and pathogenesis. These findings have significant implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms of DENV infection and the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

    **Title:** Development and Field-Testing of an Integrated Threshold Mapping Methodology for Neglected Tropical Diseases

    **Research Question:** Can an integrated mapping protocol be developed and field-tested to determine whether thresholds for public health interventions have been reached for lymphatic filariasis (LF), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) in endemic countries?

    **Methods:** We developed and field-tested the Integrated Threshold Mapping (ITM) Methodology, a novel integrated mapping protocol for LF, trachoma, schistosomiasis, and STH. The protocol relies on World Health Organization (WHO) recommended indicators in disease-specific age groups and is designed to be resource-efficient. We tested the protocol in one district each in Mali and Senegal, comparing it to current WHO mapping methodologies for each disease.

    **Main Findings:** The ITM methodology reached the same conclusions as the WHO methodologies regarding the initiation of public health interventions for trachoma, LF, and STH, but resulted in more targeted intervention recommendations for schistosomiasis. The ITM protocol was found to be practical, feasible, and cost-saving compared to the standard, non-integrated, WHO methodologies.

    **Implications:** The ITM methodology has the potential to facilitate the implementation of much-needed programs in endemic countries by providing a logistically practical, cost-efficient, and flexible approach to determining whether thresholds for public health interventions have been reached.

    **Conclusions:** This study demonstrates the effectiveness of the ITM methodology as an operational tool for Ministries of Health in NTD-endemic countries to determine if the threshold needed to launch disease-specific public health interventions has been reached. The ITM protocol can provide district-level data in a timely manner, addressing the need for integrated mapping approaches in NTD-endemic countries.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Histone Modifications Regulate Cdc14 Release from Nucleolar Chromatin during Mitotic Exit in Saccharomyces cerevisiae

    **Research Question:** How do histone modifications influence the release of the conserved phosphatase Cdc14 from nucleolar chromatin during mitotic exit in Saccharomyces cerevisiae?

    **Methods:** We employed a combination of genetic and biochemical approaches to investigate the role of histone modifications in the release of Cdc14 from nucleolar chromatin during mitotic exit. We analyzed the genetic interactions between histone ubiquitination, histone methylation, and the mitotic exit network (MEN) in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

    **Main Findings:** Our results reveal a novel requirement for the ubiquitination of histone H2B by the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase in the cell cycle-dependent release of Cdc14 from nucleolar chromatin when the MEN is inactivated. This function is mediated by the activation of histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79 (meH3K4 and meH3K79). Notably, this process is not dependent on the histone deacetylase (HDAC) Sir2, which associates with Cdc14 on nucleolar chromatin as part of the RENT complex. We also observed defects in Cdc14 release in cells lacking H3 lysine 36 methylation (meH3K36) and in cells lacking an HDAC recruited by this modification.

    **Implications:** These findings highlight the importance of histone modifications in regulating the accessibility to and/or action on nucleolar chromatin of FEAR network components. The non-redundant role of these modifications in this context contrasts with the notion of a highly combinatorial code by which histone marks act to control biological processes.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides evidence for a role for the conserved ubiquitin ligase Bre1 and monoubiquitination of histone H2B in the early phase of mitotic exit. These findings suggest that histone modifications play a critical role in regulating the release of Cdc14 from nucleolar chromatin during mitotic exit in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The conservation of these histone modifications from yeast to mammals suggests that their role in controlling localization of Cdc14 may also be conserved.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** GeneProgram: A Novel Computational Framework for Identifying Expression Programs in Human Gene Expression Compendia

    **Research Question:** How can we develop a computational framework to identify expression programs, sets of co-expressed genes orchestrating normal or pathological processes, from large compendia of human gene expression data?

    **Methods:** We developed GeneProgram, an unsupervised computational framework based on Hierarchical Dirichlet Processes, to address the challenges of cellular inhomogeneity, genetic and environmental variation, uncertainty in the numbers of programs and sample populations, and temporal behavior. GeneProgram simultaneously organizes tissues into groups and genes into overlapping programs with consistent temporal behavior, producing maps of expression programs sorted by generality scores that exploit the automatically learned groupings.
