    **Implications:** Our findings provide the first evidence that OCRL1 regulates endocytic trafficking in vivo and support the hypothesis that endocytic defects are responsible for the renal tubulopathy in Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease. Moreover, our results reveal PIP5K as a potential therapeutic target for these disorders.

    **Conclusions:** In summary, our study demonstrates that OCRL1 is essential for endocytic trafficking in the zebrafish pronephric tubule, and that its deficiency leads to impaired endocytosis. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the pathogenesis of Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease, and highlight the potential of PIP5K as a therapeutic target for these disorders. Further studies are warranted to explore the therapeutic potential of PIP5K inhibition in the treatment of these diseases.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

Title: Post-Epidemic Transmission of Rift Valley Fever Virus in Livestock Populations in Southern Tanzania: A Cross-Sectional Sero-Survey

Background: Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that affects both livestock and wild ruminants in Eastern Africa. While RVF outbreaks occur in cycles of 5-15 years, evidence of inter-epidemic transmission has increasingly been reported in parts of Africa. This study aimed to investigate the presence and determinants of inter-epidemic RVF transmission in an area experiencing annual flooding in southern Tanzania.

Methods: A cross-sectional sero-survey was conducted in randomly selected cattle, sheep, and goats in the Kilombero river valley from May to August 2011, approximately four years after the 2006/07 RVF outbreak in Tanzania. The exposure status to RVF virus (RVFV) was determined using two commercial ELISA kits detecting IgM and IgG antibodies in serum. Information about determinants was obtained through structured interviews with herd owners.

Findings: An overall seroprevalence of 11.3% (n=1680) was recorded, with 5.5% in animals born after the 2006/07 RVF outbreak and 22.7% in animals present during the outbreak. A linear increase in prevalence was observed in the post-epidemic annual cohorts. Nine inhibition-ELISA positive samples were also positive for RVFV IgM antibodies, indicating recent infection. The spatial distribution of seroprevalence exhibited a few hotspots, and animals living >15 km from the flood plain were more likely to have antibodies than those living <5 km (OR 1.92; 95% CI 1.04-3.56).

Implications: These findings indicate post-epidemic transmission of RVFV in the study area, with a constant exposure and presence of active foci of recent transmission preceding the survey. The study highlights the importance of active serological surveillance in detecting inter-epidemic transmissions, which can pass undetected clinically.

Conclusions: This study provides baseline information on the exposure status to RVFV in livestock populations during the inter-epidemic period and assesses the relationship between RVF seropositivity, animal characteristics, and environmental factors. The results suggest that post-epidemic transmission of RVFV is ongoing in the study area, emphasizing the need for continued surveillance and control measures to prevent future outbreaks.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Unconventional Trafficking of GPI-Anchored Proteins to the Plasma Membrane of Trypanosoma cruzi via the Contractile Vacuole Complex

    **Research Question:** What is the role of the contractile vacuole complex (CVC) in the trafficking of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins to the plasma membrane of Trypanosoma cruzi, an obligate intracellular pathogen that causes Chagas disease?

    **Methods:** We used a combination of genetic and biochemical approaches to investigate the contribution of the CVC to the trafficking of GPI-anchored proteins to the plasma membrane of T. cruzi. We generated a dominant-negative mutant of TcRab11, a protein that localizes to the CVC, and expressed it in T. cruzi epimastigotes. We also co-localized GPI-anchored proteins, including trans-sialidase (TcTS), mucins, and trypomastigote small surface antigen II (TcTSSA II), with GFP-TcRab11 in different stages of the T. cruzi life cycle.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that GPI-anchored proteins, including TcTS, mucins, and TcTSSA II, are trafficked to the plasma membrane of T. cruzi via an unconventional pathway involving the CVC. The CVC is enriched in lipid rafts and is essential for the trafficking of TcTS to the plasma membrane. Expression of the dominant-negative TcRab11 mutant prevented TcTS from reaching the plasma membrane and reduced the infectivity of T. cruzi trypomastigotes. However, incubation of these mutants with exogenous recombinant active TcTS and a sialic acid donor partially rescued their infectivity.

    **Implications:** Our findings reveal a novel mechanism of GPI-anchored protein secretion in eukaryotic cells and highlight the importance of the CVC in the trafficking of TcTS to the plasma membrane of T. cruzi. This study provides new insights into the biology of T. cruzi and has implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies against Chagas disease.

    **Conclusions:** In summary, our study demonstrates that the CVC plays a crucial role in the trafficking of GPI-anchored proteins to the plasma membrane of T. cruzi, and that TcRab11 is essential for this process. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of the biology of T. cruzi and the development of novel therapeutic strategies against Chagas disease.
Title: Evaluation of a Purified Chick-Embryo Cell Rabies Vaccine Administered via a Shortened Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Regimen: A Phase III Clinical Trial

    Abstract:
    This phase III clinical trial aimed to investigate the immunogenicity and safety of a purified chick-embryo cell rabies vaccine (PCECV) administered according to a shortened post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) 4-site/1-week intradermal regimen compared to the currently recommended 2-site/Thai Red Cross (TRC) regimen. A total of 443 participants received the 4-site/1-week regimen, while 442 participants received the 2-site/TRC regimen. The primary objective was to assess the non-inferiority of the 4-site/1-week regimen to the 2-site/TRC regimen in terms of the percentage of participants with rabies virus neutralizing antibody (RVNA) concentrations ≥0.5 IU/mL at day 49 post-first vaccination.

    Methods:
    This controlled, open-label, multi-center study enrolled healthy individuals ≥1 year of age and randomized them into four groups to receive intradermal PCECV according to one of the two regimens, with or without human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) administration at the first visit (in adults only). Rabies virus neutralizing antibody (RVNA) concentrations and percentages of participants with RVNA concentrations ≥0.5 IU/mL were assessed up to day 365 post-first vaccination.

    Main Findings:
    The results showed that the 4-site/1-week regimen was non-inferior to the 2-site/TRC regimen in terms of the percentage of participants with RVNA concentrations ≥0.5 IU/mL at day 49. The elicited immune responses peaked at day 14 and subsequently declined up to day 365. RVNA concentrations were consistently lower in individuals with concomitant HRIG administration compared to adults not receiving HRIG. The two regimens had similar safety profiles, with no vaccination-related serious adverse events reported.

    Implications:
    The findings suggest that the 4-site/1-week regimen might be an alternative to current recommendations, offering potential benefits in terms of improved cost-efficiency and compliance to vaccination. This regimen could be particularly useful in resource-limited settings where intradermal vaccination is preferred due to its cost-effectiveness.

    Conclusions:
    In conclusion, this phase III clinical trial demonstrated the non-inferiority of the 4-site/1-week PEP regimen to the 2-site/TRC regimen in terms of immunogenicity and safety. The results support the use of the 4-site/1-week regimen as an alternative to current recommendations for post-exposure prophylaxis against rabies, particularly in resource-limited settings.
Title: Unveiling the Dynamic Spatiotemporal Organization of the Salience Network: A Novel Graph-Theoretical Analysis of Large-Scale Brain Dynamics

Abstract:
The salience network (SN), a critical component of the human brain, plays a pivotal role in detecting and attending to goal-relevant events in a flexible manner. Leveraging the subsecond resolution of large multisession fMRI datasets from the Human Connectome Project, we employed novel graph-theoretical techniques to investigate the dynamic spatiotemporal organization of the SN. Our results reveal that the SN exhibits distinctive and robust properties, including high temporal flexibility, spatial diversity, and node centrality. Notably, time-varying connectivity profiles of the SN are distinct from all other prefrontal control systems, including the frontoparietal network (FPN), cingulate-opercular network (CON), and ventral and dorsal attention networks (VAN and DAN). Furthermore, we found that temporal flexibility of the SN uniquely predicts individual differences in cognitive flexibility. Importantly, these findings were replicated in a second retest dataset, demonstrating the robustness of our results. Our study provides fundamental new insights into the dynamic functional architecture of the SN and highlights its unique position in facilitating interactions with multiple functional systems, thereby supporting a wide range of cognitive processes in the human brain.

Research Question:
What are the dynamic spatiotemporal properties of the salience network (SN) in the human brain, and how do they relate to cognitive flexibility?

Methods:
We analyzed large multisession fMRI datasets from the Human Connectome Project using novel graph-theoretical techniques to investigate the dynamic functional interactions of the SN at subsecond temporal resolution. We focused on the spatial and topological properties of SN interactions within a whole-brain system, including key nodes of the SN and a large set of brain regions implicated in various cognitive paradigms.

Main Findings:
1. The SN demonstrated the highest levels of flexibility in time-varying connectivity with other brain networks, including the FPN, CON, VAN, and DAN.
2. Dynamic functional interactions of the SN were among the most spatially varied in the brain.
3. SN nodes maintained a consistently high level of network centrality over time, indicating that this network is a hub for facilitating flexible cross-network interactions.
4. Time-varying connectivity profiles of the SN were distinct from all other prefrontal control systems.
5. Temporal flexibility of the SN uniquely predicted individual differences in cognitive flexibility.

Implications:
Our findings provide novel insights into the dynamic functional architecture of the SN and highlight its unique position in facilitating interactions with multiple functional systems, thereby supporting a wide range of cognitive processes in the human brain. These results have significant implications for our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying flexible cognitive behaviors and may inform the development of novel therapeutic strategies for cognitive disorders.

Conclusions:
Our study demonstrates that the SN exhibits distinctive and robust properties, including high temporal flexibility, spatial diversity, and node centrality. These findings provide fundamental new insights into the dynamic functional architecture of the SN and highlight its unique position in facilitating interactions with multiple functional systems, thereby supporting a wide range of cognitive processes in the human brain. Our results have significant implications for our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying flexible cognitive behaviors and may inform the development of novel therapeutic strategies for cognitive disorders.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** VP4: A Novel Viroporin Mediating SV40 Viral Release through Membrane Perforation

    **Research Question:** What is the role of VP4, a late-expressed SV40 gene product, in the release of nonenveloped viruses from host cells?

    **Methods:** To investigate the function of VP4, water-soluble VP4 was expressed and purified as a GST fusion protein from bacteria. Purified VP4 was then tested for its ability to bind and disrupt biological membranes using flotation assays and release of fluorescent markers encapsulated into large unilamellar vesicles or liposomes.

    **Main Findings:** Our results demonstrate that VP4 efficiently binds and disrupts biological membranes, forming pores of ∼3 nm inner diameter in mammalian cells, including permissive SV40 host cells. The central hydrophobic domain of VP4 is essential for membrane binding and disruption. VP4 displays a preference for membranes comprised of lipids that replicate the composition of plasma membranes over nuclear membranes. Phosphatidylethanolamine, a lipid found at high levels in bacterial membranes, inhibits the membrane perforation activity of VP4.

    **Implications:** These findings support a central role of VP4 as a viroporin in the perforation of cellular membranes to trigger SV40 viral release. The release of viral particles by cell lysis after adequate numbers of viral particles have been assembled ensures the efficient spread of the virus. The identification of VP4 as a viroporin provides new insights into the poorly understood process of nonenveloped viral release.

    **Conclusions:** Our results demonstrate that VP4 is a novel viroporin that plays a crucial role in the release of nonenveloped viruses, such as SV40, from host cells. The membrane disruption properties of VP4 are mediated by its hydrophobic domain, which interacts with the membrane bilayer to form pores of ∼3 nm inner diameter. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of viral release mechanisms and may provide new targets for the development of antiviral therapies. Further studies are needed to determine the specific cellular membranes that VP4 interacts with during viral infection.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Elucidating the Immune Response to a DNA Vaccine Candidate Against Dengue Virus (DENV)

    **Research Question:** What is the contribution of cellular and humoral responses elicited by a DNA vaccine candidate, pcTPANS1, encoding the DENV2 NS1 protein, to protective immunity against DENV?

    **Methods:** We investigated the immune response to pcTPANS1 in Balb/c mice challenged with DENV2. Mice were immunized with pcTPANS1, and their immune responses were characterized by measuring anti-NS1 antibodies, T cell responses, and cytokine production.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that pcTPANS1 induces a robust protection against DENV, characterized by significant levels of anti-NS1 antibodies and T cell responses. Passive immunization with anti-NS1 antibodies conferred partial protection in mice infected with low virus load, but not with high virus load. The vaccine also induced activation of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, with CD8+ T cells producing IFN-γ and exhibiting cytotoxic activity. However, the contribution of CD8+ T cells to protection was not evident compared to CD4+ cells. Depletion of CD4+ cells in immunized mice completely abolished protection.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the protective immune response induced by pcTPANS1 requires cooperation between CD4+ T cells and humoral immunity. Transfer experiments revealed that animals receiving CD4+ T cells combined with anti-NS1 antiserum, both obtained from vaccinated mice, survived virus infection with survival rates not significantly different from pcTPANS1-immunized animals.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides new insights into the immunity elicited by DENV NS1 antigen and highlights the importance of CD4+ T cells and humoral responses in protection against DENV. These findings have significant implications for the development of an effective anti-dengue vaccine, which is urgently needed to control the spread of DENV in tropical and subtropical regions. Our results suggest that a DNA vaccine encoding the NS1 protein, such as pcTPANS1, may be a promising approach for inducing protective immunity against DENV.
Title: Elucidating the Structure-Function Relationship of the Transcription Factor ComR: A Novel Member of the RNPP Family in Streptococci

    Abstract:
    In Gram-positive bacteria, cell-to-cell communication relies heavily on extracellular signaling peptides that regulate various biological processes, including sporulation, conjugation, and virulence. The RNPP family of proteins, comprising Rgg and original regulators Rap, NprR, PrgX, and PlcR, plays a crucial role in these processes. Here, we investigate the structure-function relationship of ComR, a new member of the RNPP family, which positively controls competence for natural DNA transformation in streptococci. Our study reveals that ComR is directly activated by the binding of its associated pheromone XIP, leading to the release of its sequestered HTH domain and dimerization, allowing DNA binding. We propose an original molecular mechanism of ComR regulation, which is conserved and specific to ComR orthologues. Our findings demonstrate that ComR is not an Rgg protein, but rather a new member of the RNPP family. Furthermore, we identify XIP and ComR residues important for competence activation, providing a crucial step towards designing antagonistic strategies to control gene exchanges among streptococci.

    Methods:
    We employed a combination of crystal structure analysis, mutational analysis, and in vivo assays to elucidate the structure-function relationship of ComR from Streptococcus thermophilus.

    Main Findings:
    Our results show that XIP binding induces the release of the sequestered HTH domain and ComR dimerization, allowing DNA binding. This activation mechanism is conserved and specific to ComR orthologues, distinguishing ComR from Rgg proteins. We also identify XIP and ComR residues important for competence activation.

    Implications:
    Our study provides a detailed molecular mechanism of the ComR activation process, offering opportunities to engineer well-controlled peptide-based expression systems in streptococci and other Gram-positive bacteria. The identification of XIP and ComR residues important for competence activation constitutes a crucial step towards designing antagonistic strategies to control gene exchanges among streptococci.

    Conclusions:
    In conclusion, our research elucidates the structure-function relationship of ComR, a new member of the RNPP family, and provides insights into the molecular mechanism of its regulation. Our findings have significant implications for the development of new antibacterial agents and the control of gene exchanges among streptococci.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    Title: Functional Characterization of the Pentameric Ligand-Gated Ion Channel ELIC

    Research Question: What are the activating ligands and functional properties of the pentameric ligand-gated ion channel ELIC, and how does it relate to other ionotropic neurotransmitter receptors?

    Methods: This study employed a combination of electrophysiology and X-ray crystallography to investigate the functional characterization of ELIC. A library of molecules was screened to identify agonists of ELIC based on the chemical features of the ligand binding site. A bound ligand was located in a crystal structure, and the functional properties of the channel were characterized by electrophysiology.

    Main Findings: ELIC is activated by a class of primary amines, including the neurotransmitter GABA, at high micro- to millimolar concentrations. The ligands bind to a conserved site and evoke currents that slowly desensitize over time. ELIC forms cation-selective channels with properties that resemble the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. The high single-channel conductance and simple functional behavior of ELIC make it an attractive model system for studying general mechanisms of ion conduction and gating in this important family of neurotransmitter receptors.

    Implications: The identification of activating ligands for ELIC has made it amenable for detailed structural and functional investigations. This study provides new insights into the mechanisms by which the binding of ligands induces channel activation over a large distance in a different part of the protein. ELIC's ion conduction properties are closely related to those of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, serotonin receptors, and GLIC.

    Conclusions: This study demonstrates that ELIC is a cation-selective channel that is essentially impermeable to anions. The crystal structure of ELIC, which shows a non-conducting conformation of the channel obtained in the absence of ligands, is likely closer to the desensitized state of the channel. Further investigation is needed to determine its relationship to the resting state of eukaryotic receptors.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Thymic Stromal Lymphopoietin (TSLP) Drives the Atopic March from Atopic Dermatitis to Allergic Asthma

    **Research Question:** What is the molecular mechanism underlying the progression from atopic dermatitis (AD) to allergic asthma, also known as the atopic march?

    **Methods:** We used a mouse model with skin-barrier defects to study the development of AD-like skin inflammation and allergic asthma. We generated mice with keratinocyte-specific deletion of RBP-j, which resulted in high systemic levels of thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP). We also used outbred K14-TSLPtg mice that maintained high systemic levels of TSLP without developing skin pathology.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that mice with skin-barrier defects develop AD-like skin inflammation and are susceptible to allergic asthma. We found that TSLP, overexpressed by skin keratinocytes, is the systemic driver of bronchial hyper-responsiveness. Antigen-induced allergic challenge to the lung airways of RBP-j-deficient animals resulted in a severe asthmatic phenotype not seen in similarly treated wild-type littermates. Elimination of TSLP signaling in these animals blocked the atopic march, demonstrating that high serum TSLP levels are required to sensitize the lung to allergic inflammation. Furthermore, we showed that epidermal-derived TSLP is sufficient to trigger the atopic march, sensitizing the lung airways to inhaled allergens in the absence of epicutaneous sensitization.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that selective inhibition of systemic TSLP may be a key strategy to block the development of asthma in AD patients. We propose that in addition to early treatment of primary skin-barrier defects, targeting TSLP signaling could prevent the progression from AD to asthma.

    **Conclusions:** Our study provides a novel molecular mechanism for the atopic march, highlighting the role of TSLP in driving the progression from AD to allergic asthma. These findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent asthma in individuals with AD.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Elucidating the Genome Organization of Thermotoga maritima: A Hyperthermophilic Bacterium with Distinctive Properties

    **Research Question:** How does the genome organization of Thermotoga maritima, a phylogenetically deep-branching, hyperthermophilic bacterium, differ from other bacteria, and what are the implications of these differences for our understanding of microbial life on Earth?

    **Methods:** We developed an integrated approach that combines multiple omics datasets (whole-genome resequencing, transcription start site determination, transcriptome profiling, and proteome profiling) with bioinformatics tools to characterize the genome of T. maritima. This approach enabled the improvement of gene annotation, elucidation of transcription units, identification of putative non-coding RNAs, and determination of promoters and ribosome binding sites.

    **Main Findings:** Our analysis revealed several distinctive properties of the T. maritima genome, including a high number of genes per transcription unit (3.3), a paucity of putative non-coding RNAs (12), and few transcription units with multiple transcription start sites (3.7%). Quantitative analysis of promoters and ribosome binding sites showed increased sequence conservation relative to other bacteria. The 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) followed an atypical bimodal length distribution, and transcriptional regulation was limited by a lack of intergenic space for the majority of transcription units. Furthermore, a high fraction of annotated genes were expressed independently of growth state, and a linear correlation between mRNA and protein abundance was observed (Pearson r = 0.63, p < 2.2 × 10^(-16)).

    **Implications:** These distinctive properties are hypothesized to be a reflection of T. maritima's hyperthermophilic lifestyle and could yield novel insights into the evolutionary trajectory of microbial life on Earth. The integrated approach described here enables an experimentally anchored annotation of several bacterial genomic features, including protein-coding genes, functional RNAs, non-coding RNAs, transcription units, promoters, ribosome binding sites, and regulatory sites.

    **Conclusions:** Our study demonstrates the power of integrating multiple omics datasets with bioinformatics tools to elucidate the genome organization of a hyperthermophilic bacterium. The distinctive properties of the T. maritima genome provide a unique perspective on the evolution of microbial life on Earth and highlight the potential of this approach for studying the genomes of other microbial species.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Contextual Influences on Visual Perception: A Bayesian Model of Visual Inference

    **Research Question:** How do contextual inputs influence visual object recognition and sensitivity to image features, particularly in the presence of weak or missing input contrast at the target location?

    **Methods:** In this study, human observers judged the presence or absence of a target bar at the center of a display, given a weak or missing input contrast at the target location, with or without a context of other bars. We used simple visual stimuli of bars familiar in psychophysical and physiological studies of input sensitivities.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that observers are more likely to perceive a target when the context has a weaker rather than stronger contrast. When the context can perceptually group well with the would-be target, weak contrast contextual bars bias the observers to perceive a target relative to the condition without contexts, as if to fill in the target. In contrast, high-contrast contextual bars, regardless of whether they group well with the target, bias the observers to perceive no target. A Bayesian model of visual inference is shown to account for the data well, illustrating that the context influences perception in two ways: (1) biasing observers' prior belief that a target should be present according to visual grouping principles, and (2) biasing observers' internal model of the likely input contrasts caused by a target bar.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the context does not influence the perceived target contrast despite its influence on the bias to perceive the target's presence, thereby suggesting that cortical areas beyond the primary visual cortex are responsible for the visual inferences. This study provides new insights into the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and highlights the importance of contextual influences on visual object recognition.

    **Conclusions:** Our results demonstrate that contextual inputs can significantly influence visual perception, particularly in the presence of weak or missing input contrast at the target location. The Bayesian model of visual inference provides a framework for understanding these contextual influences and highlights the role of prior beliefs and internal models in shaping visual perception. These findings have implications for our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and may inform the development of new models of visual processing.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Defectors Can Rescue Cooperation in Structured Populations

    **Research Question:** Can the presence of defectors, individuals that exploit common goods without contributing fairly, lead to the persistence of cooperation in structured populations?

    **Methods:** We employed an individual-based approach to model stochastic birth, death, migration, and mutation events in a structured population. We used a combination of deterministic differential equations and stochastic simulations to investigate the effects of defectors on cooperation.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that defectors can create conditions that rescue cooperation in three ways. Firstly, during defector-induced population collapse, defectors occasionally go extinct before cooperators by chance, allowing cooperator-only populations to grow. Secondly, defectors cause population extinction, creating empty locations that support cooperator but not defector migrants. This leads to the counterintuitive result that the initial presence of defectors can sometimes improve the survival of cooperators. Thirdly, resource limitation, precipitated by defectors, selects for rare cooperator and defector mutants adapted to this limitation, further reducing local population size and favoring cooperation.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that defectors can provide a "built-in" mechanism for the persistence of cooperation in structured populations. By creating small population sizes, defectors increase variability in cooperator frequency across different locations, allowing cooperators to outgrow defectors globally despite defectors outgrowing cooperators in each location. This challenges the conventional wisdom that cooperation is vulnerable to exploitation by defectors.

    **Conclusions:** Our study demonstrates that the presence of defectors can have a paradoxical effect on cooperation, leading to its persistence in structured populations. We predict that in a structured population, small population sizes precipitated by defectors provide a "built-in" mechanism for the persistence of cooperation. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of cooperation in natural populations and highlight the complex interplay between cooperation and exploitation.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Dead Cell Tropism of Pseudomonas aeruginosa: A Novel Host Defense Mechanism against Opportunistic Pathogens

    **Research Question:** How does Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an opportunistic pathogen, interact with the epithelial barrier, and what role does efferocytosis play in eliminating this pathogen?

    **Methods:** We investigated the interaction between P. aeruginosa and a polarized epithelium using confocal microscopy and electron microscopy. We observed that P. aeruginosa adheres almost exclusively to sites of multi-cellular junctions, where it binds to extruded apoptotic cells or apoptotic bodies. We further demonstrated that P. aeruginosa is internalized through efferocytosis, a process in which surrounding epithelial cells engulf and dispose of extruded apoptotic cells.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that P. aeruginosa exhibits dead cell tropism, binding to both apoptotic and necrotic cells. We found that P. aeruginosa is internalized by surrounding epithelial cells through efferocytosis, where it inhabits an efferocytic phagosome that acquires lysosomal features. Intracellularly, P. aeruginosa is eliminated after 24 hours.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that efferocytosis is a host defense mechanism that eliminates P. aeruginosa, an opportunistic pathogen. This mechanism is particularly relevant in contexts where the epithelial barrier is compromised, such as in cystic fibrosis, where an exacerbated number of apoptotic cells and ineffective efferocytosis may facilitate P. aeruginosa colonization.

    **Conclusions:** Our study reveals a novel interaction between P. aeruginosa and the epithelial barrier, highlighting the importance of efferocytosis in eliminating this opportunistic pathogen. These findings have implications for understanding the pathogenesis of P. aeruginosa infections and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to prevent or treat infections in individuals with compromised epithelial barriers.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Investigating the Role of the Hedgehog Pathway in Primordial Germ Cell Migration during Drosophila Embryogenesis

    **Research Question:** What is the role of the hedgehog (hh) pathway gene shifted (shf) in directing primordial germ cell (PGC) migration during Drosophila embryogenesis?

    **Methods:** We used a combination of loss- and gain-of-function experiments to investigate the role of shf in PGC migration. We also examined the expression of shf and other hh pathway genes, including hmgcr, qm, and gγ1, in the gonadal mesoderm and their effects on PGC migration.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that shf is required for PGC migration and is expressed in the gonadal mesoderm. We also found that the production of the PGC attractant depends on shf and a second hh pathway gene, gγ1. Furthermore, we demonstrate that ectopic expression of hmgcr in the nervous system promotes the release/transmission of the Hh ligand from these cells into and through the underlying mesodermal cell layer, where Hh can contact migrating PGCs. Finally, we show that potentiation of Hh by hmgcr appears to depend on cholesterol modification.

    **Implications:** Our findings provide new insights into the role of the hh pathway in PGC migration during Drosophila embryogenesis. The results suggest that shf plays a crucial role in directing PGC migration by facilitating the long-distance transmission of Hh through the proteoglycan matrix. Our study also highlights the importance of the hmgcr-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway in generating the PGC attractant.

    **Conclusions:** In conclusion, our study demonstrates that shf is essential for PGC migration and that the hh pathway plays a critical role in directing PGC migration during Drosophila embryogenesis. The findings of this study provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying PGC migration and have implications for our understanding of the development of the Drosophila gonad.
Title: Enhanced Cytotoxic Capacity of HIV-Specific CD8+ T-Cells in Recipients of a Replication-Incompetent Adenovirus Serotype 5 (Ad5) HIV-1 Recombinant Vaccine: Implications for HIV Vaccine Design

    Abstract:

    Background: Understanding the mechanisms underlying protection from HIV infection or immune control over HIV replication is crucial for the development of effective HIV vaccines. Long-term nonprogressors (LTNP), individuals with durable control over HIV replication, exhibit increased cytotoxic capacity of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells, which efficiently eliminate HIV-infected CD4+ T-cell targets.

    Methods: We investigated the cytotoxic capacity of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells in response to primary autologous HIV-infected CD4+ T-cell targets in samples from HIV-negative individuals vaccinated with a replication-incompetent adenovirus serotype 5 (Ad5) HIV-1 recombinant vaccine. We compared these responses with those of HIV-negative individuals and chronically infected patients, including a group of LTNP.

    Main Findings: We observed readily detectable HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell recall cytotoxic responses in vaccinees at a median of 331 days following the last immunization. The magnitude of these responses was not related to the number of vaccinations or the percentages of cytokine-secreting T-cells determined by ICS assays. However, vaccine recipients carrying the HLA class I alleles B*27, B*57, or B*58, associated with immune control over HIV replication in chronic infection, exhibited significantly higher cytotoxic responses.

    Implications: Our findings suggest that protective HLA class I alleles may lead to better outcomes in both chronic infection and following immunization due to more efficient priming of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell cytotoxic responses. These results have significant implications for HIV vaccine design, highlighting the importance of considering HLA class I allele associations in vaccine development.

    Conclusions: This study provides the first direct measurements of recall cytotoxic capacity assessed by granzyme B target cell activity and infected CD4+ T-cell elimination in recipients of an HIV vaccine. Our results demonstrate that HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell cytotoxic responses can be induced by a replication-incompetent Ad5 HIV-1 recombinant vaccine, and that protective HLA class I alleles may enhance these responses. These findings contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms underlying HIV immune control and have important implications for the development of effective HIV vaccines.
Title: Modeling the Coevolution of Jointly Intentional Behavior and Cumulative Culture: A Unified Mechanism for the Emergence of Shared Intentions and Collaborative Behavior in Humans

Abstract:

The evolution of modern human cognition is hypothesized to have been catalyzed by the development of jointly intentional modes of behavior, where individuals collaborate to achieve common goals. This shared intentionality hypothesis suggests that the emergence of complex cognitive abilities in humans was facilitated by a high degree of collaborative behavior among early hominins relative to other great apes. We formally model the coevolution of jointly intentional behavior and cumulative culture, demonstrating that rapid techno-cultural advance is closely linked to the emergence of the ability to participate in jointly intentional behavior. Conversely, in the absence of opportunities for significant techno-cultural improvement, the ability to undertake jointly intentional behavior is selected against. Our results provide a unified mechanism for the suppression or emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans, as well as a potential cause of inter-species diversity in the prevalence of such behavior.

Methods:

We employed a computational model to simulate the evolution of jointly intentional behavior and cumulative culture in a population of individuals with varying levels of cognitive abilities. The model allowed us to investigate the effects of jointly intentional behavior on the speed of convergence to improved technological norms.

Main Findings:

Our results show that the emergence of jointly intentional behavior is closely linked to rapid techno-cultural advance. When individuals can share intentions and adjust their choice of strategy in tandem with their neighbors, the population converges to improved technological norms more quickly. Conversely, in the absence of opportunities for significant techno-cultural improvement, the ability to undertake jointly intentional behavior is selected against.

Implications:

Our findings provide a unified mechanism for the suppression or emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans. The model suggests that the evolution of jointly intentional behavior is closely tied to the emergence of complex cognitive abilities, and that rapid techno-cultural advance is a key driver of this process. The results also provide a potential explanation for inter-species diversity in the prevalence of collaborative behavior.

Conclusions:

Our study provides a formal model of the coevolution of jointly intentional behavior and cumulative culture, demonstrating that rapid techno-cultural advance is closely linked to the emergence of the ability to participate in jointly intentional behavior. The results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of human cognition and the emergence of complex social behavior.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Identification of miR-34 Family as Critical Regulators of Spermatogenesis and Male Fertility

    **Research Question:** What is the role of microRNA (miRNA) in regulating spermatogenesis and male fertility?

    **Methods:** We conducted an expression screen to identify miRNA loci specifically and highly expressed in post-mitotic male germ cells. We then generated mice deficient in the miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci to study the effects on spermatogenesis and fertility.

    **Main Findings:** We found that the miR-34 family, specifically miR-34b/c and miR-449, is highly expressed in post-mitotic male germ cells and plays a critical role in regulating spermatogenesis. Deletion of both miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci resulted in oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, characterized by reduced sperm count, aberrant sperm morphology, and impaired motility. Analysis of miR-34bc−/−;449−/− pachytene spermatocytes revealed a small cohort of genes deregulated, which were highly enriched for miR-34 family target genes.

    **Implications:** Our study identifies the miR-34 family as the first functionally important miRNAs for spermatogenesis, whose deregulation is causal to oligoasthenoteratozoospermia and infertility. The loss of miR-34bc/449 did not block spermatogenesis per se, but impaired several developmental transitions, resulting in a low sperm count and sperm of aberrant morphology and motility.

    **Conclusions:** Our results suggest that the miR-34 family plays a crucial role in regulating meiosis and the final stages of spermatozoa maturation. The deregulation of miR-34b/c and miR-449 is a definitive causal event in the genesis of oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, the most common cause of reduced male fertility or infertility in humans. This study highlights the importance of miRNAs in regulating spermatogenesis and provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying male infertility. Further research is needed to fully understand the role of miR-34 family in spermatogenesis and to explore potential therapeutic strategies to restore fertility in individuals with oligoasthenoteratozoospermia.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Decoupling the Antagonistic and Genotoxic Activities of Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN)

    **Background:** Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) has been used therapeutically for over a century, yet the determinants of its probiotic properties remain unclear. EcN produces two siderophore-microcins (Mcc) responsible for antagonistic activity against other Enterobacteriaceae and the genotoxin colibactin, encoded by the pks island, which is a virulence factor and putative pro-carcinogenic compound.

    **Research Question:** Can we decouple the antagonistic activity of EcN from its genotoxic activity?

    **Methods:** We used a combination of genetic and biochemical approaches to investigate the role of the pks-encoded ClbP peptidase in the antagonistic activity of EcN. We generated a series of ClbP mutants and analyzed their ability to inhibit the growth of pathogenic bacteria while producing beneficial secondary metabolites.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that ClbP is required for the antagonistic activity of EcN, and that this activity is linked to the transmembrane helices of ClbP, not the periplasmic peptidase domain. We also found that a single amino acid substitution in ClbP inactivates the genotoxic activity but maintains the antagonistic activity. In an in vivo salmonellosis model, this point mutant reduced clinical signs and fecal shedding of Salmonella similarly to the wild-type strain, whereas the clbP deletion mutant could neither protect nor outcompete the pathogen.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the antagonistic activity of EcN is due to siderophore-Mcc, and that the ClbP-dependent antibacterial effect is also observed in other E. coli strains that carry both a truncated form of the Mcc gene cluster and the pks island. This interplay between colibactin, salmochelin, and siderophore-Mcc biosynthetic pathways suggests that these genomic islands were co-selected and played a role in the evolution of E. coli from phylogroup B2.

    **Conclusions:** Decoupling the antagonistic from the genotoxic activity of EcN by specifically inactivating ClbP peptidase domain opens the way to the safe use of EcN as a probiotic. Our study highlights the fine margin between pathogenicity and probiotic activity and underscores the need to address both the effectiveness and safety of probiotics.
Title: Elucidating the Role of Nucleotide Sugar Transporters in Cryptococcus neoformans Glycan Biosynthesis and Virulence

    Abstract:

    Background: Cryptococcus neoformans is a deadly opportunistic pathogen responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths annually due to its ability to cause fungal meningitis. Glycans play a crucial role in the survival and pathogenesis of C. neoformans, with the polysaccharide capsule being a major virulence factor.

    Research Question: What is the role of nucleotide sugar transporters (NSTs) in C. neoformans glycan biosynthesis and virulence?

    Methods: We investigated the subcellular localization, expression patterns, and kinetic parameters of two NSTs, Uxt1 and Uxt2, which are specific for the xylose donor, UDP-xylose. We also examined their ability to transport the galactofuranose donor, UDP-galactofuranose.

    Main Findings: We found that Uxt1 and Uxt2 exhibit distinct subcellular localization, expression patterns, and kinetic parameters. Both proteins transport UDP-xylose and UDP-galactofuranose, and are required for xylose incorporation into capsule and protein. Furthermore, Uxt1 and Uxt2 are necessary for C. neoformans to cause disease in mice, although surprisingly not for fungal viability in the context of infection.

    Implications: Our findings provide a starting point for deciphering the substrate specificity of an important class of transporters, elucidate a synthetic pathway that may be productively targeted for therapy, and contribute to our understanding of fundamental glycobiology.

    Conclusions: Our study highlights the critical role of NSTs in C. neoformans glycan biosynthesis and virulence. The identification of Uxt1 and Uxt2 as UDP-Xyl/UDP-Galf transporters expands our understanding of cryptococcal glycan biosynthesis, including the sequence and localization of capsule synthetic events, and sets the stage for studies of an unusual mutant that may help elucidate mechanisms of cryptococcal pathogenesis and host response. These findings have significant implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies against C. neoformans infections.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Development of a Global Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) Database for Spatial Disease Risk Modeling and Control

    **Research Question:** Can a georeferenced global database be developed to provide open-access to available survey data for neglected tropical diseases (NTDs), enabling researchers and disease control managers to support control interventions and monitoring?

    **Methods:** We systematically searched peer-reviewed journals and grey literature, contacted Ministries of Health and research institutions in schistosomiasis-endemic countries, and extracted location-specific prevalence data and survey details for schistosomiasis in Africa. The data were georeferenced and stored in a MySQL database with a web interface, allowing free database access and data management.

    **Main Findings:** Our database currently contains over 12,000 georeferenced schistosomiasis survey locations from 35 African countries, available at http://www.gntd.org. The database has been expanded to include other NTDs, such as soil-transmitted helminthiasis and leishmaniasis. An open-access, spatially explicit NTD database offers unique opportunities for disease risk modeling, targeting control interventions, disease monitoring, and surveillance.

    **Implications:** The development of a global NTD database enables detailed geostatistical analyses of disease distribution in space and time, facilitating informed decision-making for disease control and elimination efforts. This database can be used to identify high-risk areas, monitor disease trends, and evaluate the effectiveness of control interventions.

    **Conclusions:** We demonstrate the feasibility of establishing and running a global NTD database, with an initial focus on schistosomiasis in Africa. Our database provides a valuable resource for researchers, disease control managers, and other stakeholders to support the control and elimination of NTDs. We recommend expanding the database to include other NTDs, such as lymphatic filariasis, onchocerciasis, and trachoma, to further enhance its utility and impact.
Title: Chronic Helminth Infections Do Not Exacerbate Mycobacterium tuberculosis Infection in Cotton Rats

    Abstract:

    Background: Chronic helminth infections are known to induce a Th2 immune shift, which can suppress Th1 immunity necessary for controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) infection. We hypothesized that chronic helminth infections may exacerbate the course of MTB infection.

    Methods: Co-infection studies were conducted in cotton rats, a natural host for the filarial nematode Litomosoides sigmodontis and an excellent model for human MTB. Immunological responses, histological studies, and quantitative mycobacterial cultures were assessed two months after MTB challenge in cotton rats with and without chronic L. sigmodontis infection.

    Main Findings: Contrary to our hypothesis, MTB loads and the occurrence and size of lung granulomas were not increased in co-infected animals. Spleen cell proliferation and interferon gamma production in response to purified protein derivative were similar between co-infected and MTB-only infected animals.

    Implications: These findings suggest that chronic filaria infections do not exacerbate MTB infection in the cotton rat model. While these results suggest that filaria eradication programs may not facilitate MTB control, they indicate that it may be possible to develop worm-derived therapies for autoimmune diseases that do not substantially increase the risk for infections.

    Conclusions: Our study demonstrates that chronic filarial infection does not alter control of MTB in the cotton rat model. Histological examinations and quantitative MTB cultures from two independent experiments clearly demonstrated equivalent or reduced mycobacterial burden in co-infected animals compared to those infected with only MTB. These results have significant implications for the development of worm-derived therapies for autoimmune diseases and suggest that filaria eradication programs may not be necessary for MTB control.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** The DEG/ENaC Channel PPK23 Contributes to Male Courtship Behavior in Drosophila melanogaster

    **Research Question:** What is the physiological function of the DEG/ENaC channel PPK23 in Drosophila melanogaster, and how does it contribute to male courtship behavior?

    **Methods:** We used a combination of molecular biology and behavioral assays to investigate the expression and function of PPK23 in Drosophila melanogaster. We examined the expression of PPK23 in chemosensory neurons and its role in male courtship behavior, as well as its response to the female-specific aphrodisiac pheromone 7,11-HD.

    **Main Findings:** We found that PPK23 is expressed in a subpopulation of sexually dimorphic gustatory-like chemosensory bristles that are distinct from those expressing feeding-related gustatory receptors. Disrupting PPK23 or inhibiting activity of PPK23-expressing neurons did not alter gustatory responses, but delayed the initiation and reduced the intensity of male courtship. Furthermore, mutations in PPK23 altered the behavioral response of males to the female-specific aphrodisiac pheromone 7,11-HD.

    **Implications:** Our data indicate that PPK23 and the cells expressing it play an important role in the peripheral sensory system that determines sexual behavior in Drosophila. We propose that PPK23 is a potential candidate for a pheromone receptor or a key component of the pheromonal signaling cascade.

    **Conclusions:** Our study reveals a novel physiological function for the DEG/ENaC channel PPK23 in male courtship behavior in Drosophila melanogaster. We demonstrate that PPK23 contributes to processes underlying male sexual behavior, including attraction to the female-specific aphrodisiac pheromone 7,11-HD. These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying sex-related behaviors in Drosophila and highlight the importance of DEG/ENaC channels in sensory functions. Future studies will investigate the genetic and physiological interactions between PPK23 and other receptors implicated in Drosophila courtship behaviors.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Mitochondrial tRNA Import in Chlamydomonas: A Co-evolutionary Adaptation to Mitochondrial Codon Usage

    **Research Question:** How does mitochondrial tRNA import adapt to changes in mitochondrial codon usage in the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas?

    **Methods:** We manipulated the Chlamydomonas mitochondrial genome by introducing point mutations to modify its codon usage, specifically replacing the GGC and GGT Glycine codons with the GGG codon. We then analyzed the effects on mitochondrial translation, tRNA levels, and respiratory complex activities.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that the modification of mitochondrial codon usage leads to reduced levels of mitochondrial translation, decreased tRNA levels, and impaired respiratory complex activities. These effects are linked to the limitations of the tRNA pool in mitochondria, indicating that tRNA mitochondrial import is not a dynamic process that can rapidly adapt to changes in mitochondrial codon usage.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that the steady-state levels of imported tRNAs in mitochondria result from a co-evolutionary adaptation between the tRNA import mechanism and the requirements of the mitochondrial translation machinery. This implies that the information residing in the mitochondrial DNA defines the levels of imported tRNAs to ensure optimal mitochondrial translation.

    **Conclusions:** Our study demonstrates that mitochondrial tRNA import in Chlamydomonas is not a dynamic process that can rapidly adapt to changes in mitochondrial codon usage. Instead, it is a co-evolutionary adaptation that ensures the optimal translation of mitochondrial genes. These findings have important implications for understanding the regulation of mitochondrial translation and the evolution of mitochondrial genomes in plants. Future work should focus on characterizing the tRNA import machinery and the first stages of tRNA import to further elucidate the mechanisms underlying this co-evolutionary adaptation.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given biology research article:

    **Title:** Unveiling Heterogeneity in Glucose Dysregulation: A Novel Approach to Understanding Diabetes and Prediabetes

    **Research Question:** Can continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) be used to identify specific patterns of glycemic responses, or "glucotypes," that reveal heterogeneity within traditional diagnostic categories of glucose regulation, and do these patterns predict the risk of progression to type 2 diabetes?

    **Methods:** We conducted a study using CGM to evaluate glycemic responses to standardized meals in individuals with normoglycemia, prediabetes, and type 2 diabetes. We developed an analytical framework to group individuals according to specific patterns of glycemic responses, or glucotypes, and compared these patterns to traditional measures of glucose intolerance and diabetes.

    **Main Findings:** Our results show that even individuals considered normoglycemic by standard measures exhibit high glucose variability using CGM, with glucose levels reaching prediabetic and diabetic ranges 15% and 2% of the time, respectively. We identified four distinct glucotypes, each characterized by unique patterns of glycemic responses to standardized meals. Notably, severe glucose variability was present in 25% of normoglycemic individuals, and within this subgroup, glucose reached prediabetic or diabetic glucose levels 15% and 2% of the time, respectively.

    **Implications:** Our findings suggest that glucose dysregulation, as characterized by CGM, is more prevalent and heterogeneous than previously thought and can affect individuals considered normoglycemic by standard measures. We propose that an increase in glucose variability might precede the currently used measures defining abnormal glucose levels and thus represent an even earlier stage of "prediabetes." Our results also highlight the personal nature of glucose regulation, with individual glucotypes reflecting variable underlying physiology.

    **Conclusions:** This study demonstrates the utility of CGM in identifying specific patterns of glycemic responses that reveal heterogeneity within traditional diagnostic categories of glucose regulation. Our findings have important implications for the early detection and prevention of type 2 diabetes, and we propose that identification of severe glucotypes via CGM may have greater predictive value for the development of type 2 diabetes than traditional tests.
Title: EDR1 Negatively Regulates the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 Kinase Cascade in Arabidopsis to Fine-Tune Plant Innate Immunity

    Abstract:

    Background: Mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase signaling cascades play crucial roles in regulating plant defense responses. The Raf-like MAP kinase kinase kinase (MAPKKK) EDR1 has been identified as a negative regulator of plant defense responses and cell death. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying EDR1's function and its impact on MAPK cascades remain poorly understood.

    Research Question: How does EDR1 regulate the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade in Arabidopsis, and what are the implications for plant innate immunity?

    Methods: We employed a combination of genetic, biochemical, and molecular biology approaches to investigate the role of EDR1 in regulating the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade in Arabidopsis. We generated edr1 mutants, MKK4 and MKK5 loss-of-function mutants, and overexpressed MKK4 and MKK5 in Arabidopsis.

    Main Findings: We found that edr1 mutants exhibit highly activated MPK3/MPK6 kinase activity and higher levels of MPK3/MPK6 proteins compared to wild-type plants. EDR1 physically interacts with MKK4 and MKK5, and this interaction requires the N-terminal domain of EDR1. EDR1 also negatively affects MKK4/MKK5 protein levels. Furthermore, the mpk3, mkk4, and mkk5 mutations suppress edr1-mediated resistance, and overexpression of MKK4 or MKK5 causes edr1-like resistance and mildew-induced cell death.

    Implications: Our data indicate that EDR1 negatively regulates the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade through direct interaction with MKK4 and MKK5 to modulate plant defense and cell death. This study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying EDR1's function and highlights the importance of the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade in plant innate immunity.

    Conclusions: Our findings demonstrate that EDR1 directly associates with MKK4 and MKK5, and negatively affects protein levels of MKK4, MKK5, MPK3, and MPK6, which may represent an important mechanism that fine-tunes plant defense responses. The identification of mkk4 and mkk5 loss-of-function mutants and the demonstration of their enhanced susceptibility to powdery mildew provide direct genetic evidence that MKK4 and MKK5 are key players in plant immunity responses.

**Title:** Spatiotemporal Prediction of Infectious Diseases using Gaussian Processes: A Novel Computational Framework

**Research Question:** Can a computational framework based on Gaussian processes be developed to accurately predict the spatiotemporal dynamics of infectious diseases, outperforming traditional machine learning algorithms?

**Methods:** We developed a novel computational framework that leverages Gaussian processes to perform spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. Our framework exploits the special structure of similarity matrices to obtain an efficient implementation. We tested our framework on the problem of modeling Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) cases in Turkey between 2004 and 2015.

**Main Findings:** Our results show that the Gaussian process formulation outperformed two standard machine learning algorithms, random forests and boosted regression trees, under temporal, spatial, and spatiotemporal prediction scenarios. Our framework's ability to capture highly nonlinear dependencies enabled it to make more reliable predictions.

**Implications:** The development of this computational framework has significant implications for public health policy makers. By providing accurate spatiotemporal predictions, our framework can inform decision-making and resource allocation, ultimately contributing to the control and prevention of infectious diseases.

**Conclusions:** Our study demonstrates the potential of Gaussian processes in spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. The proposed framework's efficiency and accuracy make it a valuable tool for public health policy makers. By leveraging the strengths of Gaussian processes, our framework can help mitigate the impact of infectious diseases, saving lives and reducing the economic burden on healthcare systems. Future work will focus on applying this framework to other infectious diseases and exploring its potential for real-time surveillance and outbreak detection.

Title: Investigating the Transmission Dynamics of Rift Valley Fever Virus among Ruminants in Northeastern Africa: A Three-Patch Model Approach

Abstract:
Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that causes significant economic losses and human deaths in Africa and the Middle East. This study proposes an almost periodic three-patch model to investigate the transmission dynamics of RVF virus (RVFV) among ruminants with spatial movements in Northeastern Africa. Our findings indicate that human activities, including those associated with the Eid al-Adha feast, combined with climatic factors such as rainfall level and hydrological variations, contribute to the transmission and dispersal of the disease pathogen. We show that sporadic outbreaks may occur when two events occur together: (1) abundant livestock are recruited into areas at risk from RVF due to the demand for the religious festival, and (2) abundant numbers of mosquitoes emerge.

Our numerical results present the transmission dynamics of the disease pathogen over both short and long periods of time, particularly during the festival time. We investigate the impact on patterns of disease outbreaks in each patch brought by festival- and seasonal-driven factors, such as the number of livestock imported daily, the animal transportation speed from patch to patch, and the death rate induced by ceremonial sacrifices. Our simulations show that when the time for festival preparation starts earlier than usual, the risk of massive disease outbreaks rises, particularly in patch 3 (the place where the religious ceremony will be held).

This study highlights the importance of considering human activities and climatic factors in understanding the transmission dynamics of RVFV among ruminants in Northeastern Africa. Our findings have implications for predicting and controlling RVF outbreaks, particularly in areas where the Eid al-Adha feast is celebrated. The model can be extended to consider disease latencies in both hosts and vectors, and the importation of livestock carrying RVFV during disease latency, which also impact the pattern of disease outbreaks.
Title: Temporal and Spatial Changes in Human Anthrax Occurrence in Azerbaijan from 1984 to 2010: Implications for Disease Control and Management

    Abstract:
    We investigated the spatio-temporal dynamics of human anthrax in Azerbaijan from 1984 to 2010 using a combination of spatial analysis, cluster detection, and weighted least squares segmented regression. Our results revealed a significant increase in human anthrax incidence (+11.95%) from 1984 to 1995, followed by a substantial decline (-35.24%) after the initiation of preemptive livestock vaccination in 1996. Notably, the geographic distribution of human anthrax shifted eastward over time, with cases initially concentrated in the west and south during Soviet governance, and later primarily reported in eastern and northern Azerbaijan during the vaccination period. These findings underscore the importance of an integrated "One Health" approach that considers the changing geographic distribution of the disease. Our study highlights the need for continued control measures in livestock to mitigate the occurrence of human anthrax, particularly in regions with high incidence rates. The shifting patterns of human anthrax in Azerbaijan emphasize the importance of dynamic surveillance strategies and targeted interventions to prevent the spread of this zoonotic disease.

    Methods:
    We analyzed data on livestock outbreaks, vaccination efforts, and human anthrax incidence in Azerbaijan from 1984 to 2010. Spatial analysis, cluster detection, and weighted least squares segmented regression were employed to evaluate changes in the spatio-temporal distribution of anthrax.

    Main Findings:
    Our results indicate a significant increase in human anthrax incidence from 1984 to 1995, followed by a substantial decline after the initiation of preemptive livestock vaccination in 1996. The geographic distribution of human anthrax shifted eastward over time, with cases initially concentrated in the west and south during Soviet governance, and later primarily reported in eastern and northern Azerbaijan during the vaccination period.

    Implications:
    The findings of this study have important implications for disease control and management. Continued control measures in livestock are necessary to mitigate the occurrence of human anthrax, particularly in regions with high incidence rates. The shifting patterns of human anthrax highlight the need for an integrated "One Health" approach that considers the changing geographic distribution of the disease. Dynamic surveillance strategies and targeted interventions are essential to prevent the spread of this zoonotic disease.

    Conclusions:
    Our study provides a comprehensive understanding of the spatio-temporal changes in human anthrax occurrence in Azerbaijan from 1984 to 2010. The results emphasize the importance of continued control measures in livestock and the need for an integrated "One Health" approach to prevent the spread of this zoonotic disease.
Title: Elucidating the Molecular Mechanism of Polyunsaturated Fatty Acid Modulation of the Shaker Voltage-Gated Potassium Channel

    Abstract:
    Voltage-gated potassium (KV) channels play a crucial role in regulating neuronal excitability and have been implicated in the pathophysiology of refractory epilepsy. Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) have been shown to modulate the gating mechanism of KV channels, including the Shaker channel, by shifting the voltage dependence of channel activation. However, the exact molecular mechanism of PUFA-channel interactions remains elusive. To address this knowledge gap, we employed microsecond molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the interactions between the Shaker KV channel in open and closed states and a PUFA-enriched lipid bilayer. Our results reveal a putative PUFA binding site in the open state of the channel, located at the protein-lipid interface in the vicinity of the extracellular halves of the S3 and S4 helices of the voltage-sensor domain (VSD). Specifically, the lipophilic PUFA tail engages in non-specific hydrophobic interactions with the hydrophobic central core of the protein-lipid interface, while the carboxylic head group interacts with polar/charged residues at the extracellular regions of the S3 and S4 helices, encompassing the S3-S4 linker. Furthermore, our study demonstrates that saturated fatty acids (SFAs) exhibit increased conformational flexibility in their polyunsaturated carbon tails compared to saturated carbon chains, which may explain the specificity of PUFA action on channel proteins. These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanism of PUFA modulation of the Shaker KV channel and have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for refractory epilepsy.

    Research Question:
    What is the molecular mechanism of polyunsaturated fatty acid modulation of the Shaker voltage-gated potassium channel?

    Methods:
    We employed microsecond molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the interactions between the Shaker KV channel in open and closed states and a PUFA-enriched lipid bilayer.

    Main Findings:
    Our results reveal a putative PUFA binding site in the open state of the channel, located at the protein-lipid interface in the vicinity of the extracellular halves of the S3 and S4 helices of the VSD. The lipophilic PUFA tail engages in non-specific hydrophobic interactions with the hydrophobic central core of the protein-lipid interface, while the carboxylic head group interacts with polar/charged residues at the extracellular regions of the S3 and S4 helices, encompassing the S3-S4 linker.

    Implications:
    These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanism of PUFA modulation of the Shaker KV channel and have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for refractory epilepsy.

    Conclusions:
    Our study elucidates the molecular mechanism of PUFA modulation of the Shaker KV channel, revealing a putative PUFA binding site and specific interactions between the PUFA and the channel protein. These findings have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for refractory epilepsy and highlight the importance of further research into the molecular mechanisms of PUFA-channel interactions.

    **Title:** Development of a Novel Assay Pipeline for Evaluating Anti-Cryptosporidial Activity of Inosine Monophosphate Dehydrogenase (IMPDH) Inhibitors

    **Research Question:** Can a genetically engineered Toxoplasma gondii model be used to accelerate the in vivo screening of inhibitors of Cryptosporidium parvum IMPDH and identify novel anti-cryptosporidial therapeutics?

    **Methods:** We developed a pipeline of tools to evaluate the anti-cryptosporidial activity of IMPDH inhibitors, including a genetically engineered T. gondii model that mirrors the purine pathway of C. parvum and depends on CpIMPDH for survival. We also established a fluorescence-based assay of host cell proliferation and a C. parvum growth assay that utilizes automated high-content imaging analysis for enhanced throughput.

    **Main Findings:** We used these assays to evaluate C. parvum IMPDH inhibitors emerging from our ongoing medicinal chemistry effort and identified a subset of 1,2,3-triazole ethers that exhibit excellent in vivo selectivity in the T. gondii model and improved anti-cryptosporidial activity. Two promising candidates, A103 and A110, were identified as >100× more potent than paromomycin, the current standard for anticryptosporidial activity.

    **Implications:** The development of this assay pipeline has overcome a significant roadblock in the discovery of novel anti-cryptosporidial therapeutics, which has been hampered by the poor experimental tractability of C. parvum. The T. gondii model provides a rapid assessment of anti-parasitic potential and a quantitative read of target specificity, allowing for the identification of promising candidates that can be further evaluated in C. parvum.

    **Conclusions:** Our study demonstrates the feasibility of using a genetically engineered T. gondii model to accelerate the in vivo screening of IMPDH inhibitors and identify novel anti-cryptosporidial therapeutics. The development of this assay pipeline has the potential to accelerate the discovery of effective treatments for cryptosporidiosis, a significant disease burden among children in developing countries and a life-threatening condition in AIDS patients.

    **Title:** Genome-Wide Association Study Identifies Genetic Loci Regulating Primary Dentition in Humans

    **Research Question:** What are the genetic loci associated with time to first tooth eruption and number of teeth at one year of age in humans?

    **Methods:** We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of 4,564 individuals from the 1966 Northern Finland Birth Cohort (NFBC1966) and 1,518 individuals from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC). We tested for associations between genetic variants and time to first tooth eruption and number of teeth at one year of age.

    **Main Findings:** We identified 5 loci at P<5×10−8 and 5 with suggestive association (P<5×10−6). The identified loci included several genes with links to tooth and other organ development, such as KCNJ2, EDA, HOXB2, RAD51L1, IGF2BP1, HMGA2, and MSRB3. Notably, genes at four of the identified loci are implicated in the development of cancer. A variant within the HOXB gene cluster was associated with occlusion defects requiring orthodontic treatment by age 31 years.

    **Implications:** Our findings provide new insights into the genetic architecture of primary dentition and suggest that genetic determinants of early tooth eruption may associate with dental occlusion later in life. The identified genes have roles in organogenesis, growth, and developmental processes, and mutations in three of these genes (KCNJ2, EDA, and IGF2BP1) lead to altered organogenesis and development.

    **Conclusions:** This study provides the first detailed insight into the genetic architecture of primary dentition and has implications for the study of other developmental and organogenic processes. The identification of genetic loci associated with tooth development may lead to a better understanding of the genetic basis of tooth agenesis, a common developmental anomaly in humans. Furthermore, the association between genetic determinants of early tooth eruption and dental occlusion later in life highlights the importance of considering the interplay between tooth development and other growth and developmental processes.
